properties.Name: Dimock, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Dimock is perhaps the town hardest hit by hydraulic fracturing accidents.

A drill site entrance near the spill site in Dimock, PA. (Abrahm Lustgarten / ProPublica) (http://www.propublica.org/article/frack-fluid-spill-in-dimock-contaminates-stream-killing-fish-921)
A series of spills at a natural gas site run by Cabot Oil and Gas leaked an estimated 8,000 gallons of dangerous drilling fluids. At least one incident caused fluid to spill into a creek, where a fish kill was reported. And in 2008, two separate 800-gallon diesel spills occurred in the town in June and July.
Other oddities that have occurred since fracking began include: water in parts of the town turned brown and sickened residents, a creek turned red, a woman's water well exploded, and some pets and horses mysteriously lost their hair.

Source: "A Colossal Fracking Mess." (http://www.vanityfair.com/business/features/2010/06/fracking-in-pennsylvania-201006) Christopher Bateman. Vanity Fair. June 21, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "Danger spills over well sites." (http://citizensvoice.com/news/danger-spills-over-well-sites-1.856970) Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "Frack Fluid Spill in Dimock Contaminates Stream, Killing Fish." (http://www.propublica.org/article/frack-fluid-spill-in-dimock-contaminates-stream-killing-fish-921) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. September 21, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Clearville, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
After fracking operations began on a Clearville farm, the owner's livestock mysteriously began having motor-skill breakdowns followed by sudden death. A veterinarian said the deaths may have been caused by arsenic, high levels of which were found in water on the farmer's property.

Source: "A Colossal Fracking Mess." (http://www.vanityfair.com/business/features/2010/06/fracking-in-pennsylvania-201006) Christopher Bateman. Vanity Fair. June 21, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Avella, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
On an Avella property where Atlas Energy was engaged in hydraulic fracturing, a wastewater impoundment (where the fracking fluid that makes its way back to the surface is stored) caught fire and exploded. Flames went 200 feet into the air, burned for six hours, and produced a thick, black smoke cloud visible ten miles away.
Soil sampled on the site was found to contain arsenic at 6,430 times the permissible level and tetrachloroethene (a carcinogen and central-nervous-system suppressant) at 1,417 times the permissible level.

Source: "Fears of tainted water well up in western Colorado." (http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13535728) Nancy Lofholm. Denver Post. November 11, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: De Beque, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
A spring near Logan Mountain (just outside De Beque) is believed to have been contaminated after hydraulic fracturing began in the area.
(http://www.propublica.org/article/frack-fluid-spill-in-dimock-contaminates-stream-killing-fish-921)
Ned Prather smells a cup of water from his spring. (William Woody, Special to The Denver Post) (http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13535728)
The spring was found to contain a carcinogenic and nervous system-damaging mix of chemicals known as BTEX—benzene, toluene, ethylbenzine and xylene.
BTEX and other volatile organic compounds come to the surface during the oil and gas extraction processes.

Source: "Fears of tainted water well up in western Colorado." (http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_13535728) Nancy Lofholm. Denver Post. November 11, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Rifle, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
A veterinarian in Rifle, Colorado says that after hydraulic fracturing began nearby, funny things started happening to animals in the area. A bull went sterile; pigs and a herd of beef cows stopped going into heat; sheep from an organic dairy farm had a string of mysterious still births.
All of these incidents occurred not far from drilling waste pits, where wastewater that includes fracturing fluids is dumped.
(http://www.propublica.org/article/frack-fluid-spill-in-dimock-contaminates-stream-killing-fish-921)
Jose Lara, with his family. (Grand Junction Sentinel) (http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/articles/worker_believes_cancer_caused)
Also, a man who worked for a drilling company cleaning tanks that contained hydraulic fracturing fluids believes his contact with those fluids caused his cancer. The man, 42, has incurable pancreatic and liver cancer.

Source: "Worker believes cancer caused by fracking fluids." (http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/articles/worker_believes_cancer_caused) Dennis Webb. Grand Junction Sentinel. May 11, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "Buried Secrets: Is Natural Gas Drilling Endangering U.S. Water Supplies?" (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. May 11, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.                                                                                                                    Thomas Thompson and his wife live near an Encana gas production facility. They report noxious fumes from their air and water, as well as nosebleeds, vomiting blood and illness. According to the Thompsons, company representatives intimidated people who oppose drilling.

Source: "Coloradans living near drilling operations recount health issues". Bruce Finley. The Denver Post. January 9, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_22342757/citizens-recount-health-woes-oil-and-gas-commissioners

properties.Name: Monongahela, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Used fracking fluids are sent to sewage treatment plants, which process the water and then discharge it into places like southwestern Pennsylvania's Monongahela River, a source of drinking water for more than 700,000 people.

Monongahela River. (Jon Dawson) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/jmd41280/3006859282/)
In October 2008, the levels of dissolved solids in a 70-mile stretch of the river soared above government standards. Though regulators said the water posed no serious threat to human health, the area's tap water carried an unpleasant gritty or earthy taste and smell and left a white film on dishes.
Some communities had to shift to bottled water.

Source: "Appalachia gas 'fracking' yields a foul byproduct." (http://www.tulsaworld.com/business/article.aspx?subjectid=49&articleid=20100203_49_E1_JayMil315199) Marc Levy & Vicki Smith. Associated Press. February 3, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "State says Monongahela River exceeds OK levels for drinking water." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/09219/989341-100.stm) Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. August 07, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "W.Va., Pa. Cooperate to Maintain Mon River Quality." (http://www.wvsoro.org/news/2009/01_22.html) Pam Kasey. The State Journal. January 22, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "DEP seeks cause of river pollution." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/08296/922096-100.stm) Don Hopey. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. October 22, 2008. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Blacksville, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2009, nearly all of the aquatic life was wiped out along a 30-mile stretch of Dunkard Creek, a tributary to the Monongahela River, which crosses the Pennsylvania-West Virginia border.

Flathead catfish. (Engbretson, Eric / U.S. FWS) (http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Pylodictis_olivaris.jpg)
Muskie, smallmouth bass, flathead catfish, mussels, minnows, salamanders and other organisms were killed. An estimated 10,000 fish died.
The conservation group American Rivers says the disaster was caused by a toxic golden algae bloom that occurred largely due to discharge of mining wastewater into the creek.

Source: "Monongahela River Among America's Most Endangered Rivers." (http://www.americanrivers.org/newsroom/press-releases/2010/monongahela-river-most-endangered-2010-6-2-2010.html) American Rivers. June 2, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "30-mile fish kill at Dunkard Creek." (http://www.uppermon.org/news/charleston/CG-30-Mile_Fish_Kill-Sept09.html) Ken Ward Jr. The Charleston Gazette. February 3, 2010. Accessed July 2, 2013.
Source: "With Natural Gas Drilling Boom, Pennsylvania Faces an Onslaught of Wastewater." (http://www.propublica.org/article/wastewater-from-gas-drilling-boom-may-threaten-monongahela-river) Joaquin Sapien. ProPublica. October 4, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Pavillion, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
Pavillion, Wyoming
Louis Meeks of Pavillion, Wyoming, says that his water well was contaminated after Encana drilled and fracked gas wells nearby.

Louis Meeks' well water contains methane gas, hydrocarbons, lead and copper, according to the EPA's test results. (Abrahm Lustgarten / ProPublica) (http://www.propublica.org/article/epa-chemicals-found-in-wyo.-drinking-water-might-be-from-fracking-825)
EPA officials investigated reports of contaminated drinking water from Meeks and others in Pavillion and found that at least three water wells (including Meeks') contain the toxic chemical 2-Butoxyethanol (or 2-BE), which is used in the hydraulic fracturing process.
Traces of other contaminants, including oil, gas or metals, were found in 11 of 39 wells tested. Officials say there is no indication that any industry or activity besides gas drilling could be to blame.

Source: "EPA: Chemicals Found in Wyo. Drinking Water Might Be From Fracking." (http://www.propublica.org/article/epa-chemicals-found-in-wyo.-drinking-water-might-be-from-fracking-825) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. August 29, 2009.
Source: "Wyo. fracking contamination case eerily similar to Colorado's Divide Creek accident." (http://coloradoindependent.com/38146/wyo-fracking-contamination-case-eerily-similar-to-colorados-divide-creek-accident) David O. Williams. The Colorado Independent. September 18, 2009.

properties.Name: Hopewell Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Hopewell Township, PA
A 100-by-80-foot impoundment (400,000 gallon capacity) filled with wastewater produced from hydraulic fracturing exploded early Wednesday, March 31, 2010, near the rural town of Hopewell, PA.

The Atlas well burns. (Pittsburgh Post-Gazette) (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10091/1047159-58.stm)
Residents reported strong gas odors in the days preceding the loud explosion, which set the impoundment, its plastic liner, and nearby equipment on fire. The flames were reportedly one hundred feet high and a black plume of smoke was visible for miles.
Also, between December 5 and 6, 2009, at a site run by Atlas Resources, a pit containing 750,000 gallons of fresh water mixed with wastewater overflowed into a small tributary.
And in May 2009, a pipe transporting wastewater to an impoundment pit sprang a leak, sending about 5,000 gallons of wastewater into a tributary of Cross Creek Lake. A fish kill was reported.
In August 2010, the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection fined Atlas Resources $97,350 for the December 2009 spill, which was the company failed to report.

Source: "Pa. DEP fines Marcellus driller $97,000 for spill." (http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9HLEA300.htm) Associated Press. August 17, 2010.
Source: "Danger spills over well sites." (http://citizensvoice.com/news/danger-spills-over-well-sites-1.856970) Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.
Source: "Residents reported gas odors before explosion." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10091/1047159-58.stm) Janice Crompton. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. April 1, 2010.
Source: "Pennsylvania's Gas Wells Booming—But So Are Spills." (http://www.propublica.org/article/pas-gas-wells-booming-but-so-are-spills-127) Sabrina Shankman. ProPublica. January 27, 2010.

properties.Name: Clark, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
Clark, Wyoming
In August 2006, in this tiny town north of Cody, Wyoming, suffered a natural-gas well blowout.
The well vented an estimated 4 million cubic feet of natural gas into the air and about a dozen residents evacuated their homes. The blowout also sent benzene and other chemicals into wells and aquifers, contaminating drinking water.
As of June 2010, surface contamination had been mostly cleaned up, but contamination remained deep underground.

Source: "More cleanup work on 2006 Clark blowout well." (http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/wyoming/article_b6e17772-8454-11df-9415-001cc4c002e0.html) Associated Press. June 30, 2010.
Source: "Clark residents to discuss response to gas well blowout." (http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/wyoming/article_ed89e9ac-9db5-11de-8a24-001cc4c03286.html)Ruffin Prevost. Billings Gazette September 9, 2009.

properties.Name: Mt. Pleasant Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Mt. Pleasant Township, PA
In October 2009, in Mt. Pleasant Township, PA, raw natural gas escaped from a pipeline with such force that it caused nearby homes to shake.
The high pressure gas was not being burned and was released for over an hour, causing a loud sustained noise to be heard throughout the area.
One resident living about a quarter mile from the compressor station said it sounded like a "rocket taking off." He said the escaped gas caused a burning sensation in his eyes and made him cough.

Source: "Residents report Toxic Clouds of Gas near a MarkWest Compressor Station." (http://www.phillyimc.org/en/residents-report-toxic-clouds-gas-near-markwest-compressor-station) Nastassja Noell. Philadelphia Independent Media Center. October 23, 2009.                                                                                                                           A tank at a MarkWest Liberty Midstream Resources LLC compressor station in Mount Pleasant, Pennsylvania, caught fire in March of 2011, causing the hatch of a second tank to blow off.
No injuries were reported and inspectors from the DEP suspect it was caused by a malfunction of heater within the compression tank.

Source: "Tanks at Washington County Marcellus site catch fire."
http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/11060/1128846-100.stm) Jonathan D. Silver. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. March 1, 2011

properties.Name: Tioga County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Tioga County, PA
In May 2010, the state agriculture department quarantined 28 cows that may have drank toxic fracking fluids on a farm in Tioga county, in north-central Pennsylvania.


The cows had access for about three days to a pool that formed from a leaking wastewater impoundment pond, part of natural gas drilling operations occurring nearby.

Tests found chemicals including chloride, magnesium, potassium, and strontium in the water. Strontium, a heavy metal, is what most concerns officials because it can be toxic to humans.

And in June 2009, more than 30,000 gallons of diluted wastewater spilled from a waste pit after workers overfilled it. Fortunately, the wastewater was diluted enough and cleaned promptly enough that it did not kill any vegetation and did not appear to reach any streams.


Source: "Pennsylvania quarantine cattle over gas drilling fluid." (http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE66058L20100701) Reuters. July 1, 2010.

Source: "Danger spills over well sites." (http://citizensvoice.com/news/danger-spills-over-well-sites-1.856970) Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Roaring Branch, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Roaring Branch, PA
Officials in Pennsylvania are investigating a natural gas well leak, after residents near the town of Roaring Branch reported that rust-colored water was flowing from a spring and two creeks were bubbling with methane gas.

One woman was evacuated from her home as a precaution, four homes are now being delivered drinking water, and 18 homes are having their water monitored.
It is believed that a failed casing on one of the natural gas wells is to blame for the contamination.

Source: "More Gas Contamination Affects Pennsylvania Residents." (http://www.propublica.org/article/more-gas-contamination-affects-pennsylvania-residents-804) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. August 4, 2009.

properties.Name: Bradford, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Bradford, Pennyslvania

Shortly after natural gas drilling commenced in Bradford in the spring of 2008, residents began complaining of murky and foul-smelling tap water.
The Department of Environmental Protection investigated, it found methane in three water wells and metals in six others.
The drilling company has installed water filtration systems for affected residents.

Source: "Water Problems From Drilling Are More Frequent Than PA Officials Said." (http://www.propublica.org/article/water-problems-from-drilling-are-more-frequent-than-officials-said-731) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. July 31, 2009.

properties.Name: Bainbridge, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
Bainbridge, Ohio
In December 2007, a home exploded in the small town of Bainbridge, Ohio, a suburb of Cleveland. Methane entered nearby water wells and the basement of Richard and Thelma Payne's home where it was ignited by a spark.

The Ohio Department of Natural Resources later issued a 153-page report that determined a nearby gas well's faulty cement casing and hydraulic fracturing pushed methane into an aquifer and caused the explosion.
In October 2008, the home of Irvin and Joanne Mesmer filled with a dangerously high level of methane gas, which had seeped into their water well. An explosion was narrowly averted after the fire department responded and vented the home.
In total, 46 water wells in the area are contaminated by methane gas that leaked from an Ohio Valley Gas Company well into the aquifer.
Many homes now use bottled water.

Source: "Officials in Three States Pin Water Woes on Gas Drilling." (http://www.propublica.org/article/officials-in-three-states-pin-water-woes-on-gas-drilling-426) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. April 26, 2009.
Source: "Home near gas well on brink of explosion." (http://www.chagrinvalleytimes.com/NC/0/274.html ) Joan Demirjian. Chagrin Valley Times. October 22, 2008.

properties.Name: Caddo Parrish, LA
properties.PopupInfo:
Caddo Parish, LA
In 2009, 16 cattle were found dead at a natural gas well site after apparently drinking a mysterious fluid near a drilling rig.

At least one worker said the fluids were used in the hydraulic fracturing process.
More recently, in April 2010, hundreds of people were evacuated from their homes after a natural gas well blowout contaminated a drinking water aquifer.
It was not clear what contaminants were in the water, but residents were told not to drink it or even wash their clothes in it.

Source: "Louisiana Well Blowout Forces Hundreds From Homes." (http://www.propublica.org/article/louisiana-well-blowout-forces-hundreds-from-homes) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. April 20, 2010.

properties.Name: Fort Lupton, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Near Fort Lupton, Colorado, a ruptured pipe left one worker dead and two others seriously injured in November of 2014. The Haliburton workers were attempting to warm a frozen pipe when the accident occurred. The Andarko Petroleum Corps site and surrounding fracking pads were shut down at the time for safety reasons.

Source: “Fracking accident leaves 1 dead, 2 injured in Colorado” James Queally. La-Times. November 13, 2014. Accessed January 10, 2017.
http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-fracking-accident-colorado-20141113-story.html                                                                                                                                                           In rural Fort Lupton, Colorado, one resident's water began to smell funny and came out of the tap in bursts.
In February 2009, when he placed a cigarette lighter next to the running faucet, the water lit on fire.
He is one of at least 29 residents northeast of Denver who have asked government or energy company officials to test their water wells for natural gas.

Source: "Colorado Study Links Methane in Water to Drilling." (http://www.propublica.org/article/colorado-study-links-methane-in-water-drilling-422) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. April 22, 2009. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Sublette County, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2008, a hydrologist discovered that a water well in rural Sublette County, Wyoming contained foul smelling, oily brown water.

Lab tests revealed the well water contained benzene, a chemical believed to cause aplastic anemia and leukemia, in a concentration 1,500 times the level safe for people.
Subsequent tests showed contamination in 88 of the 220 wells examined in Sublette County, and the plume of contaminants stretched more than 28 miles.
When researchers returned to take additional samples, they couldn't even open the water wells; monitors indicated the wells were so full of flammable gas they were likely to explode.

Source: "Buried Secrets: Is Natural Gas Drilling Endangering U.S. Water Supplies?" (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. November 13, 2008.

In November 2013, an explosion of condensate tanks at an Encana drilling site injured five workers. One worker was listed in critical condition, while two others were said to be in serious condition. A fourth worker was listed in stable condition, while the fifth was treated and released from a Pinedale clinic. The cause of the explosion appeared to be welding work that the workers were carrying out. Condensate is a byproduct of natural gas production.

Source: "5 Encana workers injured in Jonah Field fire". Benjamin Storrow. Casper Star-Tribune. November 22, 2013. Web. Accessed July 17, 2015.
http://trib.com/business/energy/enanca-workers-injured-in-jonah-field/article_deaedce9-be1f-592e-9426-d4cc777ad961.html

properties.Name: Collbran, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Collbran, Colorado
In 2000, Ballard Petroleum built a gas well less than 250 yards from the home of Laura and Larry Amos.

Laura Amos, and her daughter. (Lynn Johnson / NRDC) (http://www.nrdc.org/OnEarth/06sum/rockies1.asp)
In May 2001, while the family was away on vacation, three wells were hydraulically fractured. That same day, the metal cap on the home's water well was blown into the air by a fountain of murky, fizzing water that flooded the surrounding pasture.
After that incident, their tap water was gray, bubbly and foul smelling. State inspectors found high levels of methane in the well, but did not test for fracking fluids.
Three years later Laura developed an adrenal gland tumor, which has since been removed.
In 2005, EnCana (which purchased Ballard) revealed that 2-BE, a carcinogenic fracking ingredient, had been used in at least one well adjacent to the Amos property.

Source: "Buried Secrets: Is Natural Gas Drilling Endangering U.S. Water Supplies?" (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. November 13, 2008.
Source: "How Halliburton Technology is Wrecking the Rockies." (http://www.nrdc.org/OnEarth/06sum/rockies1.asp) Michelle Nijhuis. OnEarth. Summer 2006.

properties.Name: Parachute, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Parachute, Colorado

A waste pit at a natural gas drilling site. (Abrahm Lustgarten / ProPublica) (http://www.propublica.org/article/how-the-wests-energy-boom-could-threaten-drinking-water-for-1-in-12-america)
In February 2008, a waste containment pit on a mesa overlooking the town of Parachute, Colorado leaked about 1.6 million gallons, including toxic fracking fluids.
The spill seeped into the groundwater and then flowed down a cliff side where it froze into a gray sheet of ice more than 200 feet tall.
When temperatures warmed up, the fluids melted into Parachute Creek which flows into the Colorado River.

Source: "How the West's Energy Boom Could Threaten Drinking Water for 1 in 12 Americans." (http://www.propublica.org/article/how-the-wests-energy-boom-could-threaten-drinking-water-for-1-in-12-america) Abrahm Lustgarten, ProPublica and David Hasemyer, The San Diego Union-Tribune. December 21, 2008.

properties.Name: Durango, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Durango, Colorado
In August 2008, an emergency room nurse in Durango, Colorado treated a oilworker who had been covered in fracking fluid in a spill at a BP natural gas rig.

Cathy Behr was in critical condition after treating an oilworker. (Abrahm Lustgarten / ProPublica) (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113)
The nurse removed the man's clothes and put them into plastic bags while the hospital sounded alarms and locked down the ER.
The worker was released, but a few days later the nurse was in critical condition facing multiple organ failure.
Her doctors pressed the manufacturer of the fracking fluid to tell them its contents. The chemical manufacturer eventually told the doctors, but the nurse was already on her way to recovery by that time.

Source: "Buried Secrets: Is Natural Gas Drilling Endangering U.S. Water Supplies?" (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. November 13, 2008.

properties.Name: Rock Springs, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
Rock Springs, WY
In June 2008, benzene was discovered in Rock Springs, Wyoming.
An oil company, Oxy, had illegally operated a pit for nearly 10 years without a permit there. Although the pit was lined, it had been torn.

Testing revealed one spring had benzene at concentrations 12 times the allowable level. An oily sheen was also found on water in a tributary of Crystal Creek.
Three weeks later a rancher was hospitalized after he drank well water out of his own faucet. Tests showed benzene in his water.

Source: "Oxy agrees to major fines for contamination of springs." (http://www.gjsentinel.com/news/articles/oxy_agrees_to_major_fines_for/) Dennis Webb. Grand Junction Sentinel. April 26, 2010.
Source: "Buried Secrets: Is Natural Gas Drilling Endangering U.S. Water Supplies?" (http://www.propublica.org/article/buried-secrets-is-natural-gas-drilling-endangering-us-water-supplies-1113) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. November 13, 2008.

properties.Name: Pine Creek Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Pine Creek Township, PA
A company that hauls waste from gas drilling sites spilled 7 tons of residual waste sludge (a.k.a. "drilling dirt") along Route 220 in Pine Creek Township in Pennsylvania.
The waste spilled from a truck when its tailgate popped open along a rough stretch of road. The company was fined $6,000 in January 2010 for the incident.

Source: "DEP Fines M.R. Dirt Inc. $6K for waste sludge spill; Towanda company's truck leaks 7 tons." (http://thedailyreview.com/news/dep-fines-m-r-dirt-inc-6k-for-waste-sludge-spill-towanda-company-s-truck-leaks-7-tons-1.558587) James Loewenstein. The Daily Review (Towanda, PA). January 20, 2010.

properties.Name: Clearfield County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Clearfield County, PA

Moshannon
State Forest.
(Nicholas / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/nicholas_t/4806370994/in/photostream/)
In June 2010, an accident at a rig drilling into the Marcellus Shale caused a geyser of gas and hydraulic fracturing wastewater to spew into the air for 16 hours.
The incident occurred on property owned by a private hunting club in the middle of Moshannon State Forest.

Source: "Danger spills over well sites." Laura Legere. The Citizens’ Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Asylum Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Asylum Township, PA

In February 2009, 295 gallons of hydrochloric acid spilled at a drill site operated by Chesapeake Appalachia, LLC in Aslyum Township, Pennsylvania.

The incident occurred after workers put the hydrochloric acid in a storage tank not designed to hold acidic contents.


Source: "Danger spills over well sites." Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

Source: "DEP Fines Chesapeake Appalachia LLC for Acid Spill." NorthcentralPA.com. June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Granville Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Granville Township, PA

In March 2009, 420 gallons of hydrochloric acid spilled at a drill site operated by Chesapeake Appalachia, LLC in Granville Township, Pennsylvania.
The acid flowed into a pond and may have caused a 30-foot area of dead or stressed vegetation, including several evergreen trees.

Source: "Danger spills over well sites." ( http://citizensvoice.com/news/danger-spills-over-well-sites-1.856970) Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Troy Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Troy Township, PA
On June 30, 2009, a worker for Fortuna Energy (now Talisman Energy) drove a tanker truck 2.5 miles on public roads between two of the company's well sites in Troy Township, Pennsylvania—all the while leaking hydrochloric acid.


The tanker lost 100 to 200 gallons of acid. The contaminated soil was later removed from both sites. The driver was taken by helicopter to the hospital after inhaling fumes trying to put a catch pan under the leak.

Also, in July and August 2009, there were four drilling wastewater spills on the same two well pads.


Source: "Danger spills over well sites." Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Penn Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Penn Township, PA
On December 12, 2009, Chief Gathering, LLC was boring a path for a pipeline 13 feet under a stream, wetland and road in Penn Township, in Lycoming County, Pennsylvania, when the synthetic muds used to drill the hole erupted to the surface.








Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
Between 3,000 and 6,000 gallons of synthetic drilling mud spilled into the wetland and some of it reached the stream.







The state's Department of Environmental Protection inspector who visited the site also discovered there had been a previously unreported spill of about 110 gallons on December 10, 2010.








Source: "Danger spills over well sites." Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Kushequa, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Kushequa, PA

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
Atlas Energy LLC, a Pennsylvania company, drilling for natural gas near Kushequa, Pennsylvania in McKean County was found to have caused explosive levels of methane and ethane to seep into residential water supplies.

The gas buildup triggered a small explosion in the town's public well in late 2007.


Source: "Danger spills over well sites." Laura Legere. The Citizens' Voice (Wilkes-Barre, PA). June 21, 2010.

properties.Name: Washington County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Washington County, PA
George Zimmerman, the owner of a 480-acre property in Washington County, in southwestern Pennsylvania, says his water has been contaminated by nearby hydraulic fracturing.
Atlas Energy, Inc. operates ten natural gas wells nearby. Zimmermann says that baseline tests on his water were "perfect" a year before drilling began.

In June 2009, tests of his water found arsenic at 2,600 times the federally acceptable level, benzene at 44 times above the standard and naphthalene at five times the standard.
Samples of Zimmerman's soil showed mercury and selenium above official limits; also found in the soil were ethylbenzene, a drilling chemical, and trichloroethene, a naturally occurring but toxic chemical that can rise to the surface due to gas drilling.

Source: "Pennsylvania lawsuit says drilling polluted water." ( http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5A80PP20091109) Jon Hurdle. Reuters. November 9, 2009.

properties.Name: Bridgeville, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Bridgeville, Pennsylvania

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
In Bridgeville, Pennsylvania, two homes exploded when a well casing failed and methane seeped into their basements.

Source: "Water Problems From Drilling Are More Frequent Than PA Officials Said." (http://www.propublica.org/article/water-problems-from-drilling-are-more-frequent-than-officials-said-731) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. July 31, 2009.

properties.Name: Dayton, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Dayton, Pennsylvania

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
In Dayton, Pennsylvania, residents were evacuated after a well casing failed and methane seeped into an adjacent abandoned well, blowing out its casing and travelling a third of a mile underground.

Source: "Water Problems From Drilling Are More Frequent Than PA Officials Said." (http://www.propublica.org/article/water-problems-from-drilling-are-more-frequent-than-officials-said-731) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. July 31, 2009.

properties.Name: Vandergrift, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Vandergrift, Pennsylvania

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
In Vandergrift, Pennsylvania, when a new gas well was hydraulically fractured, the intense pressure forced the gas into old gas wells adjacent to the drill site that the drillers did not know existed.
The gas (including methane) then percolated up through water and mud until it surfaced nearby homes in a heavily populated neighborhood.

Source: "Water Problems From Drilling Are More Frequent Than PA Officials Said." (http://www.propublica.org/article/water-problems-from-drilling-are-more-frequent-than-officials-said-731) Abrahm Lustgarten. ProPublica. July 31, 2009.                                                                                                                                                         In February 2014, 21 cars of a Norfolk Southern Railway freight train derailed in Vandergrift. Crude oil leaked from four of the derailed cars. Two other cars contained liquid propane. The train was transporting Canadian crude oil, liquid propane, soda ash and food products.

Source: "Crude oil spill contained after 21 freight cars jump tracks in Vandergrift". Jon Schmitz. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. February 14, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.post-gazette.com/local/east/2014/02/14/21-freight-cars-jump-tracks-in-Vandergrift/stories/201402140098

properties.Name: Leidy Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Leidy Township, PA

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
A natural gas well exploded into flames September 14, 2008 in Leidy Township, in Clinton County, Pennsylvania.



The fire burned for nearly two weeks and special fire fighters were called from Texas to help put out the flames.




Source: "Gas well fire is out." (http://www.lockhaven.com/page/content.detail/id/505833.html) The Lock Haven Express. September 27, 2008.



Source: "Gas well fire could burn for weeks." (http://www.lockhaven.com/page/content.detail/id/505578.html?actionAlert=emailcontent) Jim Runkle. The Lock Haven Express. September 16, 2008.

properties.Name: Hickory, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Hickory, Pennsylvania
In 2005, Range Resources began drilling a natural gas well about 900 feet from Virginia Smitsky's home.

Tap water from the Smitsky home. (Justin Merriman) (http://justinmerriman.blogspot.com/2010/08/marcellus-shale.html)
Soon after, her well water became contaminated. The water no longer tasted good and its color turned from clear to cloudy and then became brown.
Today, the water is clear, but still has an incredibly foul odor and a greasy, oily feel to it.
Virginia and her son no longer drink the water and will not bathe with it either, as it makes their skin itch. Also, five of her son's goats died during a six-month period, after they exhibited signs of dehydration.
Results of an EPA water test are pending.

Source: "A stink at the kitchen sink." Christie Campbell. Observer-Reporter (Washington, PA). March 12, 2010.
Source: "Water problem gets closer look from DEP, EPA." Christie Campbell. Observer-Reporter (Washington, PA). March 26, 2010.

properties.Name: DISH, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Dish, Texas
In 2006, a natural gas compressor station was built on the edge of Dish, Texas to transport gas extracted nearby to market.
Today, there are 11 compressors in this tiny, rural town in north Texas and they are releasing pollutants into the air day and night.

Water in the Smith family home. The filter was changed just five days ago. (DRC / Barron Ludlum) (http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/drc/localnews/stories/DRC_Filmy_Water_0606.75b6f6a3.html)
Residents there have complained of an unpleasant, sulfurous stench and have reported ailments such as headaches, nausea, eye irritation and respiratory problems. The noise of the compressor stations has also ruptured several residents' ear drums.
An air quality study ordered by the town revealed extremely high levels of both carcinogens and neurotoxins. Of particular concern is the high levels of the carcinogen benzene detected in the air near the compressors.
One family's water turned gray and filled with a fine, slimy sediment after a well was dug several hundred feet from their home. The family has installed a filtration system in their home and must change the filter every four or five days due to the buildup of mysterious sediment.
Another resident mysteriously had one horse die and two others get sick. He blames pollution from the compressor stations.

Source: "Health Issues Follow Natural Gas Drilling In Texas." (http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120043996) John Burnett. NPR. November 3, 2009.
Source: "Filmy water vexes family." (http://www.dentonrc.com/sharedcontent/dws/drc/localnews/stories/DRC_Filmy_Water_0606.75b6f6a3.html) Peggy Heinkel-Wolfe. Denton Record-Chronicle. June 5, 2010.

properties.Name: Huerfano County, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Huerfano County, CO
In the summer of 2007, in rural Huerfano county, Colorado, methane seeped into the Ben Bounds' well and exploded inside his pump house. The pump-house roof shot off the frame and everything inside was melted or singed.

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
A state inspector found that the Bounds family's water was contaminated with high levels of methane. There are 50 methane drilling wells and active hydraulic fracturing operations nearby.
The family has since installed detectors that alert them when methane levels become unsafe; they have had to evacuate their home several times.
The state has warned Mr. Bounds not to allow his grandchildren or visitors to come to the property.

Source: "Boom in gas drilling fuels contamination concerns in Colorado." (http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/2009/0205/boom-in-gas-drilling-fuels-contamination-concerns-in-colorado) Josh McDaniel. The Christian Science Monitor. February 5, 2009.

properties.Name: Silt, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Silt, Colorado
Lisa Bracken, a resident of Silt, Colorado, believes hydraulic fracturing has poisoned her water. Encana operates forty gas wells within a mile radius of her home. In 2004, methane and benzene seeped into Divide Creek on Bracken's property.

Lisa Bracken. (Courtesy photo) (http://www.gjfreepress.com/article/20090612/COMMUNITY_NEWS/906119995)
Bracken and a private geologist she hired believe the hydraulic fracturing process is to blame. The Colorado Oil and Gas Conservation Commission (COGCC), however, blamed a faulty concrete job on a gas well near Divide Creek and fined Encana a record $370,000.
Since 2004, Bracken has witnessed several incidents of foul "propane tank" odors and bubbles coming from the creek.
And in 2007, Bracken's father, an outdoorsman who often drank from the creek, died of pancreatic cancer. She believes hydraulic fracturing is to blame.

Source: "Wyo. fracking contamination case eerily similar to Colorado's Divide Creek accident." (http://coloradoindependent.com/38146/wyo-fracking-contamination-case-eerily-similar-to-colorados-divide-creek-accident) David O. Williams. The Colorado Independent. September 18, 2009.
Source: "New legislation would remove secrecy of fracking chemicals." (http://www.gjfreepress.com/article/20090612/COMMUNITY_NEWS/906119995) Sharon Sullivan. Grand Junction Free Press. June 12, 2009.

properties.Name: Varick, NY
properties.PopupInfo:
Varick, New York
In the fall of 2007, Chesapeake Energy began drilling a gas well 660 feet from Laurie Lytle's property line in Varick, New York.

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
The morning after the well was hydraulically fractured, Lytle said her water was gray and full of sediment.
After three days, the sediment was gone, but her water was still cloudy. She contacted Chesapeake and they agreed to install a water filter on her well.
At her request, Chesapeake tested her water, but they did not test for fracking fluids.

Source: "6,000 sign petition asking DEC to strengthen natural gas-drilling regulations." (http://www.theithacajournal.com/article/20091208/NEWS01/912080356/6-000-sign-petition-asking-DEC-to-strengthen-natural-gas-drilling-regulations) Krisy Gashler. The Ithaca Journal. December 8, 2009.

properties.Name: Allegany County, NY
properties.PopupInfo:
Allegany County, NY
Dave Eddy lives in Allegany County, New York, near a gas well operated by U.S. Energy Development Corporation. The company, he says, uses hydraulic fracturing to extract the gas.

In the spring of 2009, Eddy's wife filled up the bath tub for their kids and "foamy, chocolate-brown" water came out of the faucet.
Testing by U.S. Energy found the family's well was polluted with gas.
The company has since installed a water filter in the Eddy home.

Source: "Activist challenges DEC claim of few gas drilling problems." (http://www.theithacajournal.com/article/20100404/NEWS01/4040356/1126/news/Activist+challenges+DEC+claim+of+few+gas+drilling+problems) Tom Wilber. The Ithaca Journal. April 4, 2010.

properties.Name: Gibbs Hill, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Gibbs Hill, Pennsylvania
Steve Hilyer lives in Gibbs Hill, Pennsylvania nearby where Seneca Resources Inc. is actively fracking natural gas wells.


On July 30, 2008, Hilyer was woken up early in the morning by his neighbor, Clint Yates, who reported that his mouth burned after drinking his water. His wife had also taken a shower and felt her lungs burn and her sinuses flair up.

Hilyer tried the water from his tap and felt his mouth burn and an immediate headache.

The water, which comes from a natural artesian spring under the steep hill where they live, had developed a briny taste and smelled of natural gas.

The Pennsylvania DEP advised the homeowners not to use the water and Seneca is supplying water to both homes.


Source: "Gibbs Hill homeowners lose water supply after fracking." Heidi Zemach. Ridgway Record. August 11, 2008.

properties.Name: Hamilton Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Hamilton Township, PA
In June 2006, Jim Hughes Sr. and his neighbor Leonard Nelson's water was contaminated after Seneca Resources, Inc. drilled a natural gas well with 660 feet of each of their properties.

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
Hughes says that his water turned "blood red" and his pond turned pink.
The Pennsylvania DEP found that the Hughes' and Nelson's wells were contaminated with unsafe levels of methane and ordered Seneca to drill new wells for them.
When Hughes' replacement well was dug, there was so much gas collected that the well caught fire, sending flames 5–7 feet into the air.
Seneca put a burn-off pipe in the well to release the gas, which burned steadily for 3–4 months.
Hughes has filed a lawsuit against Seneca.

Source: "Hamilton resident files civil suit against Seneca Resources." Heidi Zemach. The Kane Republican. March 5, 2008.

properties.Name: Bradford Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Bradford Township, PA
In May 2009, the EPA determined Schreiner Oil and Gas Co. was to blame for contaminating the drinking water of at least seven families in Bradford Township, PA (not to be confused with Bradford, PA, another town experiencing problems with natural gas drilling).

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
EPA sampled water from 17 homes and found that two were contain methane above established drinking water standards and five contain iron and manganese above those standards.
Schreiner has been actively drilling and hydraulically fracturing wells since fall 2008.

Source: "Schreiner Oil and Gas Co. deemed responsible for harming at least seven water wells on Hedgehog Lane in Bradford Township, according to DEP." (http://www.bradfordera.com/news/article_0766dfbd-1925-5fb2-bb5c-ed4d3b567c6c.html) The Bradford Era. May 4, 2009.
Source: "Gas, oil driller blamed for polluting McKean County wells." (http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_623660.html) Pittsburgh Tribune-Review. May 5, 2009.

properties.Name: Hill County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Hill County, Texas
In December 2007, in rural Hill county Texas, just outside of Grandview, three families had their water supplies contaminated after Williams Production Gulf Coast Co. drilled two nearby gas wells.

Sayers: A hydrologist "told me not to use [the water] for anything ... not even for watering the grass." (Jimmy Alford / Fort Worth Weekly) (http://archive.fwweekly.com/content.asp?article=6885)
All three families live within a couple hundred yards of the well sites and draw their water from an underground aquifer.
The Harris family's water problems arose just two or three days after Williams hydraulically fractured one of those wells.
At all three of the affected homes, the water smells strongly of sulfur and causes itchiness if used for showering.
Williams tested the water and said it was normal, but a consultant hired by the Sayers family advised them that the company had improperly tested the water. So the Sayers family hired two companies to test their water.
The tests, conducted several weeks apart, both showed elevated ions, sulphates, and the presence of toluene. Toluene is a hydrocarbon that never naturally occurs in aquifers and is toxic to humans and animals.

Sayers makes three trips a week to get water for his family. (Jimmy Alford / Fort Worth Weekly) (http://archive.fwweekly.com/content.asp?article=6885)
The Beadle family had three goats, two kids and a lama die within a few days of each other.
All families now truck in their water.

Source: "Water Foul." (http://archive.fwweekly.com/content.asp?article=6885) Peter Gorman. Fort Worth Weekly. April 30, 2008.

properties.Name: Allegheny National Forest, McKean County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Allegheny National Forest, McKean County, PA
Between April 2007 and January 2008, 200,000 gallons of brine (wastewater leftover after the hydraulic fracturing process) were illegally dumped in the Allegheny National Forest.

Allegheny National Forest. (U.S. Forest Service)
The brine was dumped into an abandoned oil well by Swamp Angel Energy, LLC, a Kansas-based company with 77 active wells, all in McKean County.
Two men, a site supervisor and a part owner of Swamp Angel Energy, plead guilty to felony dumping violations of the Clean Water Act. In June 2010, they were assessed fines and sentenced to home detention and community service for their involvement.

Source: "Gas Drillers Plead Guilty to Felony Dumping Violations." (http://www.propublica.org/article/gas-drillers-plead-guilty-to-felony-dumping-violations) Sabrina Shankman. ProPublica. February 22, 2010.
Source: "Two Oil and Gas Drilling Operators Sentenced On Felony Convictions for Violating the Safe Drinking Water Act." (http://www.justice.gov/usao/paw/pr/2010_june/2010_06_24_04.html) Department of Justice Press Release. June 24, 2010.

properties.Name: Indiana Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Indiana Township, PA
On July 23, 2010 a natural gas well exploded in Indiana Township, killing two workers. The well is being drilled by Huntley & Huntley, a Pennsylvania company with 350 wells in the greater Pittsburgh area.

Source: "2 killed in Indiana Twp. gas well explosion." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10204/1074835-100.stm) Jim McKinnon and Dante Anthony Fuoco. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. July 23, 2010.

properties.Name: Johnson County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
The Scoma family in rural Johnson County, Texas, filed a lawsuit against Chesapeake Energy in June 2010, claiming their water became contaminated after the company began hydraulic fracturing operations nearby.

The water from their tap usually runs clear, but at times turns an orange-yellow color, gives off a foul odor, and tastes awful. The Scoma family had their water tested in 2008 and 2009 and say those tests showed elevated levels of benzene and other petroleum by-products.
The Scoma's are afraid to drink their well water and now purchase bottled water.

Source: "Local Couple Claims Gas Drilling Tainted Water." Melissa Newton. CBS 11/TXA 21 (Fort Worth). June 18, 2010.

In July 2013, two families filed a lawsuit for damage to their homes and property caused by earthquakes and seismic activity as a result of drilling by EOG Resources, Enterprise Crude Oil, and subsidiaries of Royal Dutch Shell and Sunoco Logistics. The walls of Ed Specht's house are cracking, and the concrete floor in his bedroom is broken 32 feet across. He claims the damage is a result of the dozen hydraulic fracturing wells under his property.

Source: "The fracking-earthquake connection". Jordan Fletcher. The Dallas Morning News. December 6, 2013. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/sunday-commentary/20131206-the-fracking-earthquake-connection.ece

properties.Name: Jefferson Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Jefferson Township, PA
In December 2007, a coalbed methane gas well operated by Atlas America Inc. exploded, killing one worker and seriously injuring another.
The incident occurred in Jefferson township, Pennsylvania.

Source: "Gas well incident claims 1 in Greene County." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10204/1074835-100.stm) Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. December 3, 2007.

properties.Name: Appomattox, VA
properties.PopupInfo:
Appomattox, Virginia

The explosion demolished two brick homes. (Appomattox News) (http://www.appomattoxnews.com/2008/photos-from-appomattox-gas-line-explosion.html)
In September 2008, a natural gas pipeline operated by Williams Gas exploded in a rural area outside Appomattox, Virginia.
The explosion, described as a massive fireball a quarter to a half mile long and tall, destroyed two homes and injured five people.

Source: "Appomattox Gas Line Explosion, Update." (http://www.appomattoxnews.com/2008/appomattox-gas-line-explosion-update.html ) Ronnie D. Lankford. Appomattox News. September 14, 2008.

properties.Name: Cleburne, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Cleburne, Texas
A spate of small earthquakes (in the 2 to 3 range on the seismic scale) in May 2009 unsettled residents in the small town of Cleburne, Texas, which had never before experienced any earthquakes in its 142-year history.

Natural gas drilling rig. (Helen Slottje / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/arimoore/4142107176/in/photostream/)
Many residents, including the Mayor, believe hydraulic fracturing of nearby natural gas wells is to blame.
More than 200 wells have been drilled within the town's 30-square-mile border in recent years and virtually all of them have undergone hydraulic fracturing.
One University of Texas researcher believes drilling is to blame but others are not yet ready to make that conclusion.

Source: "Temblors Rattle Texas Town." (http://online.wsj.com/article/NA_WSJ_PUB:SB124476331270108225.html) Ben Casselman. Wall Street Journal. June 12, 2009.
Source: "Drilling might be culprit behind Texas earthquakes." (http://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/2009-06-15-drilling-earthquake_N.htm) Jeff Carlton. Associated Press. June 15, 2009.

properties.Name: Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
DFW International Airport, Texas
Wells drilled through the Barnett Shale by Chesapeake Energy Corp. may have caused earthquakes in Texas, according to the company and University of Texas scientists.

DFW International Airport. (Benny / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/bennylee/5585514986/in/photostream/)
The wells that have been linked to earthquakes were drilled on the South end of the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport.
Those wells were used to dispose of the saltwater byproduct of hydraulic fracturing.
The area near the airport wells has no history of seismic activity.

Source: "Chesapeake Waste Wells May Have Caused Earthquakes." (http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=akyt.PqERmjw ) Thomas Korosec and Jim Polson. Bloomberg. August 14, 2009.

properties.Name: Pavillion, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
Pavillion, Wyoming
EPA officials in September 2010 urged residents of Pavillion, Wyoming, who live near natural gas drilling sites not to use private well water for drinking or cooking because of chemical contamination.

Tests in Pavillion found that 17 of 19 wells tested contained petroleum hydrocarbons as well as naphthalene, phenols and benzene.
However, EPA officials expressed no views about the source of contamination.
Nonetheless, residents whose wells contain organic hydrocarbons will have new water supplies paid for by EnCana, the Canadian energy company that owns Pavillions approximately 250 gas wells.

Source: "US test shows water problem near natgas drill site." (http://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFN0116496920100901?sp=true) Jon Hurdle. Reuters. September 1, 2010.

properties.Name: Killdeer, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
Killdeer, North Dakota
In September of 2010, a blowout occurred at a natural gas platform in Killdeer, North Dakota, causing it to leak about 246 barrels of oil and 2,220 barrels of water.
The company responsible, Denbury Resources Inc., plugged the well contained the oil and water with a dike and recovered it.

Source: "Killdeer oil spill being cleaned up, officials investigate." (http://www.bismarcktribune.com/news/state-and-regional/article_af6a8bd2-b712-11df-b4ff-001cc4c03286.html) Lauren Donovan. Bismarck Tribune. September 2, 2010.
Source: "Killdeer spill tests ND." (http://www.bismarcktribune.com/news/opinion/editorial/article_cddc11ca-bb50-11df-9e61-001cc4c002e0.html) Bismarck Tribune Editorial Board. Bismarck Tribune. September 29, 2010.                                                                                             Also in January 2012, 21-year-old Dustin Bergsing was found dead at a Marathon Oil Corp. Buffalo 34-12H well pad. His body was slumped below the open hatch of a tank of Bakken Shale crude oil -- it was Bergsing's job to pop the hatch and record how much was inside. An autopsy found he died of "hydrocarbon poisoning due to inhalation of petroleum vapors".

Source: "Poisoned by the shale? Investigations leave questions in oil tank deaths". Mike Soraghan. EnergyWire. October 27, 2014.
http://www.eenews.net/special_reports/danger_zone/stories/1060007896                                                                                                                                        Oil wells were drilled along Loren Jepson's ranch on Killdeer Mountain. Clay mud and silt from the drill pad were running into his stock dam less than 50 yards downhill. The spring melt carried a stream of mud into the water he uses for livestock and to water his yard and garden. Jepson paid an attorney and fought a long legal battle to keep oil wells from being drilled alongside his ranch, but he lost.

Source: "Killdeer rancher has muddy spring mess from unwanted wells". Lauren Donovan. Bismarck Tribune. March 29, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://bismarcktribune.com/bakken/killdeer-rancher-has-muddy-spring-mess-from-unwanted-wells/article_06c4c334-98a7-11e2-b731-001a4bcf887a.html

properties.Name: St. Clair Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
St. Clair Township, PA

The Whipkeys go through photographs documenting development of the Flickinger Well near their St. Clair Township home. (Eric Schmadel / Tribune-Review) (http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/westmoreland/s_707625.html)
The state Department of Environmental Protection cited Texas-based XTO Energy Inc. for dumping industrial waste into Tubmill Creek while drillings its Flickinger Well in St. Clair Township in September of 2010.
2 to 3 cubic yards of bentonite leaked into the creek. According to DEP spokeswoman Katy Gresh, the drilling accident did not harm aquatic life or well-water supplies.

Source: "Texas drilling company cited for dumping waste." (http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/westmoreland/s_707625.html) Jewels Phraner. Ligonier Echo. November 4, 2010.

properties.Name: Rifle, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Rifle, Colorado

Flames from the natural gas well explosion. (KJCT 8) (http://www.kjct8.com/news/26594246/detail.html)
A natural gas well in the Beaver Creek area of Rifle, Colorado, exploded in January 2011, as flames started shooting out of the ground.
Rifle Fire Department contained the blaze to the tank and said there was minimal damage and nobody was injured.

Source: "Early Morning Natural Gas Fire South of Rifle." (http://www.kjct8.com/news/26594246/detail.html) Katie Ryan. KJCT 8. January 24, 2011.

properties.Name: Ward Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Ward Township, PA
Talisman Energy's gas well experienced a blowout in January of 2011, causing an uncontrolled discharge of sand and fracking fluids onto state forest lands in Ward Township, Pennsylvania.

Tioga State Forest. (Dave Pidgeon / Flickr) (http://www.flickr.com/photos/49246898@N06/4598442302/in/photostream/)
The well where the blowout occurred is on Pennsylvania State Forest lands in the Tioga State Forest in Ward Township, about nine miles southeast of Mansfield.
During the blowout, 21,000 gallons of fracking fluids and sand discharged from the well into the air and the well was successfully shut down later that day.

Source: "Pa. fracking blowout spews fluid onto state forest lands." (http://www.pressconnects.com/article/20110125/NEWS01/101250370/Pa.+fracking+blowout+spews+fluid+onto+state+forest+lands) G. Jeffrey Aaron. Gannett. January 25, 2011.

properties.Name: Joyfield Township, MI
properties.PopupInfo:
A leak at a 1000-foot-deep natural gas well drilled in Michigan's northwestern Lower Peninsula using fracking techniques caused a shutdown of operations in February of 2011.
The well was located in Benzie County’s Joyfield Township was closed up and was the first time a leak has been experienced in Michigan.
The leak may lead to a review of some regulations related to permits and monitoring for such wells.

Source: "Leak shuts down drilling operation at Mich. well." (http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9LA7D1G2.htm) The Associated Press. February 10, 2011. Accessed July 2, 2013.

properties.Name: Wise County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Wise County, Texas

In Wise County, Catherine and Brett Bledsoe report that their drinking water became contaminated in 2010 soon after hydraulic fracturing began on two natural gas wells bordering their property.
The water stung their eyes during showers, and their animals refused to drink the water.
Private water testing found benzene, a known carcinogen, at double the levels deemed safe by the EPA.

Source: "Unwell water." (http://www.wcmessenger.com/2010/news/unwell-water-drilling-leaves-a-bad-taste-for-some/) Brandon Evans. Wise County Messenger. October 3, 2010.

properties.Name: Tarrant County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Tarrant County, TX

Tarrant County Commissioner J.D. Johnson, who lives in the Barnett shale area, reported groundwater contamination immediately after two gas wells on his property were hydraulically fractured in 2005.
His water turned a dark gold color and had sand in it.

Source: "The Barnett Shale search for facts on fracking." (http://www.star-telegram.com/2010/09/04/2445005/the-barnett-shale-search-for-facts.html) Jack Smith. Fort Worth Star-Telegram. September 4, 2010.

properties.Name: Romance, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
Romance, West Virginia

The Hagy family in Jackson County, West Virginia, is suing four oil and gas companies for contaminating their drinking water.
They say their water had "a peculiar smell and taste." The parents, as well as their two children, are suffering from neurological symptoms.

Source: "Suit claims gas drilling contaminated well drinking water." ( http://www.wvrecord.com/news/231887-suit-claims-gas-drilling-contaminated-drinking-water) Lawrence Smith. West Virginia Record. December 10, 2010.

properties.Name: Mount Pleasant, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Mount Pleasant, PA

Damage at the compressor station. (Darrell Sapp / Post-Gazette) (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/11060/1128846-100.stm)
A tank at a MarkWest Liberty Midstream Resources LLC compressor station in Mount Pleasant, Pennsylvania, caught fire in March of 2011, causing the hatch of a second tank to blow off.
No injuries were reported and inspectors from the DEP suspect it was caused by a malfunction of heater within the compression tank.

Source: "Tanks at Washington County Marcellus site catch fire." (http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/11060/1128846-100.stm) Jonathan D. Silver. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. March 1, 2011.

properties.Name: Waterville, Pennsylvania
properties.PopupInfo:
Waterville, Pennsylvania

Pennsylvania General Co. LLC, a Warren PA based company, drilling in a state forest allowed Airfoam HD to enter the water table and discharge a foamy substance into a local spring, eventually finding its way into Pine Creek. DEP Northcentral Region Community Relations Coordinator Daniel Spadoni explains that Airfoam HD is used by natural gas drillers to create a foam that lifts water and drill cuttings to the surface. Although the company blamed rainfall and snowmelt for this incident, the discharge was a violation of regulations including Clean Streams Law and Solid Waste Management Act, which resulted in a fine of $28,960 for illegal emissions.
































































































































Source: " DEP fines company for substance spill." (http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/559751/DEP-fines-company-for-substance-spill.html?nav=5011) Patrick Donlin. Sun Gazette. February 3, 2011.

properties.Name: Penn Township, Pennsylvania
properties.PopupInfo:
Penn Township, Pennsylvania

An estimated 13,000 gallons of fracking fluid from water tanks spilled at an XTO Energy natural gas well pad off of Marquardt Rd. An inspector noticed that a valve on a 21,000 gallon fracking fluid tank was left open and spilled the fluid contaminating the Muncy Creek watershed.































































Minuteman Response trucks vacuumed the spilled fluids and excavated the surrounding area, but meter readings indicate the presence of fracking fluid.
































































































































Source:" DEP investigating frack fluid spill." (http://culogin.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/564915/Spilled-substance-that-closed-road-was-not-hazardous--DEP-says.html?nav=5052) Patrick Donlin. Sun Gazette. November 23, 2010.

properties.Name: Wallis Run Road
properties.PopupInfo:
Wallis Run Road
A slick, slippery substance caused the closing of a 10-mile stretch of road from Wallis Run Road in parts of Eldred, Gamble and Cascade townships until is it cleaned up.































































































































































































































































Although the situation is framed as a road safety issue with the substance classified as residual waste, testing revealed the substance to be a friction reducer used in the natural gas industry.
































































































































































































































































Source: "10 Miles of Foamy Fluid Closes Road." (http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/564825/10-miles-of-foamy-fluid-closes-road.html?nav=5011) Philip A. Holmes. SunGazette. June 5, 2011.































Source: "Spill substance that closed road was not hazardous, DEP says." (http://culogin.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/564915/Spilled-substance-that-closed-road-was-not-hazardous--DEP-says.html?nav=5052) Patrick DonlinSunGazette. June 7, 2011.

properties.Name: Muncy, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Muncy, PA
Methane contaminated private residential water wells and bubbled up in a northern Pennsylvania stream near a Marcellus Shale natural gas drilling operation owned by Texas-based XTO Energy.



The subsidiary of energy giant ExxonMobil Corp. halted operations in the county and provide the water well owners with potable water when flammable gas was found in five water wells in Lycoming County and in the nearby Little Muncy Creek.



Although multiple past incidents have prompted the DEP to fine Chesapeake Energy and Cabot Oil & Gas, companies drilling in Pennsylvania counties, they have not assumed responsibility for the pollution. XTO may be another corporation to add to the list.




Source: " DEP examines report of gas in Lycoming Co. wells." (http://www.pressconnects.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2011106160367) The Associated Press. Public Opinion. June 16, 2011.

properties.Name: Durango, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2012, an employee was working at a BP compression station when it exploded, killing one contract worker and injuring two others. A local BP spokeswoman said that the plant had been shut down and was no longer a threat. Eleven workers were on site at the time of the explosion.


Source: “One dead, 2 hurt in BP natgas blast in Colorado.” Eileen Houlihan, Janet McGurty and Edward McAllister. Reuters. June 26, 2012.

properties.Name: Silt Mesa, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Gas development in Silt Mesa and Peach Valley by Antero Resources has been linked to extreme air and water pollution that it has forced families from their homes. One family experienced symptoms like severe nosebleeds, blackouts and body rashes before doctors told them they had to move for their health.


Source: “Silt Mesa family claims gas fumes forcing them out. ” John Colson. Post Independent. January 4, 2011.

properties.Name: Parachute, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
When a tank full of gas condensate overflowed, a woman walking nearby collapsed, unconscious, from the fumes. The woman complained of vomiting, diarrhea, lesions, pain and elevated heart rate. Later, air tests found high levels of benzene, tetrachloroethene, and 1,4-dichlorobenzene. Her neighbors reported similar symptoms, and these symptoms are characteristic of dozens of residents of communities living in areas that have been extensively drilled. In Colorado, the ATSDR sampled air for pollutants at 14 sites for a 2008 report. Fifteen contaminants were detected at levels the federal government considers above normal.

Source: “Science Lags as Health Problems Emerge Near Gas Fields.” Abrahm Lustgarten and Nicholas Kusnetz. ProPublica. September 16, 2011.


Source: Garfield County Health Consultation. ATSDR.March 13, 2008.

properties.Name: Desoto Parish, LA
properties.PopupInfo:
A Chesapeake Energy blowout killed one, injured another, caused neighborhoods within a two mile radius to be evacuated and sent at least six Desoto Parish fire fighters to a nearby hospital. This particular blowout spewed methane into the air for around 30 minutes, officials say.
The explosion occurred while contractors performed maintenance on the well site, and was so loud that residents thought it was a bomb explosion or a plane crash. The gas well was capped the following day.

Source: “Gas well blowout in DeSoto Parish.” Ben Wolf. KSLA News. November 18, 2009.

properties.Name: Aztec, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
A woman reported breathing difficulty, dizziness, nausea, numbness in her lips, muscle weakness and headaches due to nearby gas wells.

Source: “Drilling Photo essay- Shirley McNall.” Photo: Amy Mall. Natural Resources Defense Council.

properties.Name: San Juan County, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
One ranching family in San Juan County, New Mexico noted numerous spills and leaks at well pads on the public land where their cattle graze. After losing some of their herdthey tested the other sick cattle from the area. Results from the Texas Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Laboratory in 2005 found petroleum in the hair of 54 out of 56 animals tested.

Source: “Drilling Photo essay- Blancett family.” Photo: Robert Castellino. Natural Resources Defense Council.

properties.Name: Bouttineua, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2011, workers for Petro Harvester, a small, Texas-based oil company, noticed a swath of dead vegetation in a field near one of the company’s saltwater disposal lines. The company reported the spill the next day, estimating that 12,600 gallons of brine had leaked. Later state officials who assessed the spill found that it had sterilized about 24 acres of land. The assessment estimated that 2 million gallons of brine was leaked; however, they did not record the new estimate. If they had, it would have made it the largest spill recorded in a state: state annals did not change and kept the 12,600 gallon figure.

Source: “North Dakota’s Oil Boom Brings Damage Along With Prosperity.” Nicholas Kusnetz. ProPublica. June 7, 2012.

properties.Name: Granger Township, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
January, 2012: Two homes in Granger County have been deemed a public health threat by a federal health agency because of potentially explosive levels of natural gas in their drinking water. The Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry stated that the problems with the wells originated from the nearby drilling of two gas wells. Levels of “explosivity” are considered hazardous when they exceed 10%: the wells of the two homes were at 34.7% and 47.4%. The high gas levels inside and nearby the house led Columbia Gas to shut off services for a period of time because of the likelihood of an explosion. The federal level of explosivity is 1%, and inside one of the houses measured an alarming 20%.

Source: “Three years after drilling, feds say natural gas in Medina County well water is potentially explosive.” Bob Downing. Beacon Journal. January 17, 2012.

properties.Name: Sweetwater, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2012, a Nomac Drilling Rig drilled into a shallow gas pocket, causing an explosion and fire that burnt the gas well to the ground. Witnesses nearly a mile away heard a loud “boom” from their homes and one resident claimed that it sounded “like a jet engine was right outside our home.” Nomac Drilling is a subsidiary owned by Chesapeake Energy, one of the most active drillers in the nation.

Source: “Chesapeake/Nomac Rig #17 Hits Shallow Gas Pocket-Burns To The Ground.” Drilling Ahead. January 5, 2012.

properties.Name: Bradford County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2012, methane from underground pathways caused plumes of gas in the air, which were found near Bradford County. Following the incident, both the state and the natural gas company investigated the cause of stray methane bubbling in streams and water wells, and found that the ground levels methane concentrations were twice the normal levels in the region’s air. Quote: "The amount of methane that had to come out at that point to generate that plume, that's a lot of methane," said Bryce Payne, Ph.D., the report's author and an environmental scientist at Gas Safety Inc. Later, Dr. Payne stated that the concentration levels posed an explosion risk. Two Chesapeake natural gas wells a half-mile from affected waters are under investigation, while at least five homes are now “supersaturated” with methane.

Source: “Study: Airborne methane plume found near Bradford County gas migration site.” Laura Legere. The Times-Tribune. June 27,2012
http://m.thetimes-tribune.com/news/study-airborne-methane-plume-found-near-bradford-county-gas-migration-site-1.1335347

In February 2014, Chesapeake Appalachia LLC agreed to pay Jacqueline Place $60,000 for contaminating her water well with methane. According to tests, her well water contained levels of methane hundreds of times higher than pre-drilling baseline results, as well as increased iron and turbidity.

Source: "Bradford County woman wins arbitration case with Chesapeake over well contamination". Brendan Gibbons. The Times Tribune. February 19, 2014.
http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/bradford-county-woman-wins-arbitration-case-with-chesapeake-over-well-contamination-1.1637029

In April 2011, a cracked well casing caused the Chesapeake Energy well in Bradford county to spill thousands of gallons of fracking fluid. A portion of this fluid seeped into a small, nearby stream as fluid continued to gush from the pipes.

Source: Source: “Pennsylvania Fracking Spill: Natural Gas Well Blowout Spills Thousands of Gallons Of Drilling Fluid.” The Huffington Post. April 20, 2011.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/04/20/pennsylvania-fracking-spill-gas-blowout-2011_n_851637.html

properties.Name: Union Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2012, a methane leak detected at a Marcellus fracking well led Shell to evacuate nearby residents. The suspected methane migration caused a 30 foot methane-driven geyser to erupt. According to state officials from the Department of Environmental Protection, a drinking water well located 4,000 feet from a drilling site also began overflowing

Source: “Methane Leak Detected at Marcellus Fracking Well.” Duane Nichols. EcoWatch. June 22, 2012.

properties.Name: Bradford, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Chesapeake Energy agreed to pay $1.6 million in damages to three families. Investigators found that a poor cement job led to a methane migration to local water supplies. According to reports, the Chesapeake Energy company has had 190 violations and paid nearly $1.2 million in fines so far.

Source: “Chesapeake to Pay $1.6 Million for Contaminating Water Wells in Bradford County.” Susan Phillips. NPR StateImapact: Pennsylvania. June 21, 2012

properties.Name: Washington County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Fracking water from a Dominion Resources Appalachian and Consol gas wells and impoundment overflowed into a pond where livestock drank, resulting in the death of more than 10 cattle. The fracking water or “flowback” includes the original fracking chemicals plus heavy metals, toxic levels of salt and radioactive materials.

Source: “Gas drilling impacts: PA farmer Terry Greenwood’s cows gave birth to zero calves this year, after ten dead calves in 2008.” Iris Marie Bloom. Protecting Our Waters. November 4, 2011.

In May 2014, an equipment failure at a Range Resources well pad caused a gas leak, necessitating the evacuation of about 35 local residents. According to the Department of Environmental Protection, the failure led to a release of methane into the air.

Source: "Range Resources 'Equipment Failue" leads to gas leak, precautionary evacuation in Washington County". Marcellus Monitor. May 14, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
https://marcellusmonitor.wordpress.com/2014/05/14/range-resources-equipment-failure-leads-to-gas-leak-precautionary-evacuation-in-washington-county/

Mickey Gniadek lives near an EQT gas well. One day he went outside and smelled chemicals in the air. He felt like he couldn't breathe, as if his chest was collapsing. He then developed red spots on his head, eyes and cheeks. Gniadek's neighbors also complain of chemicals smells, loud noises and health problems.

Source: "Act 13 ruling buoys residents near Trax Farm gas well". Anya Litvak. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. February 22, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://powersource.post-gazette.com/powersource/features-powersource/2014/02/23/Pennsylvania-Supreme-Court-ruling-buoys-residents-near-Trax-Farm-well/stories/201402230124#ixzz2u9Nc9kWA

properties.Name: Fort Worth, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Chesapeake drilling operations: over 15 dangerous compounds were detected on a Fort Worth home in April 2010. Certain sulfur compounds were above short term and long term screening levels, and carbon disulfide levels were 300 times higher than the EPA’s normal for ambient urban air. A resident of the tested area, suffered severe nosebleeds, nausea and headaches.

Source: “Voices: Deborah Rogers.” EarthWorks. May 2010.

Mary Kelleher lives near a Chesapeake gas well and a 30-inch Enterprise pipeline. Enterprise never got a city permit for the pipeline. Sinkholes appeared on her property, and the pipeline obstructed the area's natural drainage pattern, causing severe flooding. Farm animals, unable to reach higher ground, drowned by the dozens.

Source: "Damned: The waters have receded, but flooding near Ranol Mill isn't solved". Lisa Maria Garza. Fort Worth Weekly. July 25, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.fwweekly.com/2012/07/25/dammed/

properties.Name: Lumberton, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2011, a natural gas well exploded in Lumberton on state park property which caused a small fire to burn five acres of the park. Four workers were on the well when it exploded, though none were injured. The explosion was caused by escaping gas vapor which triggered the flash fire, and then the explosion, according to the Texas Department of Public Safety. The Texas Park and Wildlife Department and drilling company Choice Exploration of Arlington have a surface use agreement that allows the company to drill in the park, according to the article.

Source: “Four workers escape from burning natural gas well.” Teresa Mioli. Beaumont Enterprise. April 1, 2011.

properties.Name: Nixon, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2012, an explosion at Vann Energy Company in South Texas left two workers with burns. Officials from the sheriff’s office confirmed that the workers were injured while cleaning a hydraulic fracking tank when the tank exploded. The workers suffered second-degree burns and were airlifted to a nearby hospital. Nearby homes were also evacuated during the accident. Three months prior to the incident, the Occupational Health and Safety Administration had cited Vann Energy with 17 safety violations, including failure to provide workers with proper protective clothing.

Source: “South Texas fracking explosion injures two.” Law Firm of Alton C. Todd. May 24, 2012.

Source: “2 workers burned in South Texas fracking explosion.” Associated Press via Dallas News. May 16, 2012

Source: Reuters, "UPDATE 1-Two workers hurt in Texas fracking tank site blast," May 16, 2012

properties.Name: Pearsall, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2012, an explosion and fire at an Eagle Ford disposal well injured three people. An oil tank exploded and caught fire, burning for over an hour and calling 12 trucks and 33 firefighters (all volunteer) to the scene. The site was used to store wastewater from fracking.
