The growing oil boom in the Eagle Ford Shale has residents concerned: even with a rise in fracking explosions and fires, the volunteer fire department hasn’t received additional funding.
Later following the incident, in April 2012 the Occupational Health and Safety Administration issued ten citations for serious violations.

Source: “Explosion and Fire at Eagle Ford Disposal Well in Pearsall.” Terrence Henry. NPR StateImapact: Texas. January 20, 2012.

properties.Name: Lynchburg, VA
properties.PopupInfo:
A CSX train carrying crude oil from the Bakken shale in North Dakota derails in Lynchburg on April 30, 2014, setting off a 200-foot high fireball and prompting the evacuation of some 300 people. 30,000 gallons are spilled, including into the nearby James River.

Source: "The Bad Oil Boom: Train Explodes in Virginia Town While Regulators Chug Along." Matthew Philips. Los Angeles Times. April 30, 2014. Accessed July 23, 2014. http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-04-30/the-bad-oil-boom-crude-train-explodes-in-lynchburg-virginia-while-regulators-chug-along

properties.Name: Mayflower, AR
properties.PopupInfo: An ExxonMobil pipeline that ruptured in March 2013 spilled 5,000 barrels of noxious black-oil in central Arkansas. This massive spill caused widespread health concerns throughout the region: children were sent home from school after complaining of headaches and experiencing difficulty breathing due to fume exposure, and residents reported headaches, stomach aches and persistent sore throats.                                                                                                                                   Source: “Arkansas Oil Spill Health Complaints Emerge in Mayflower.” Lynne Peeples. Huffington Post. April 10, 2013.         http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/11/exxonmobil-pipeline-rupture-arkansas_n_3060280.html                                       “ExxonMobil Pipeline Rupture ‘Substantially Larger’ Than Previously Thought.” Jeannine Nuss. Huffington Post. April 10, 2013.                      http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/10/arkansas-oil-spill-health-_n_3045610.html

properties.Name: Quitman, AR
properties.PopupInfo: After a disposal well allegedly seeped fracking fluids onto their land, two families sued Southwestern Energy in August 2012.                                                                                                           Source: "Landowners Sue Gas Company Over Frack Fluid". Arkansas Business. August 27, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.                        http://www.arkansasbusiness.com/article/86409/landowners-sue-gas-company-over-frack-fluid

properties.Name: Fresno County, CA
properties.PopupInfo: A 12-inch natural gas line exploded at the Fresno County peace officers gun range in April 2015, injuring 16 people. Four individuals were in critical condition, and two others were taken to Madera Community Hospital in serious condition.                                                                                                          Source:"Gas explosion at fresno county peace officers gun range injures 16 people". Rick Montanez and Mariana Jacob. ABC 30 Action News. April 17, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015  http://abc30.com/news/northwest-fresno-gas-explosion-injures-16-people/666797/

properties.Name: Hawthorne, CA
properties.PopupInfo:
Thirty-seven families were evacuated after a retired water well spewed methane gas. As crews were conducting a routine process of capping the retired well, they experienced an unexpected outflow of water being pushed up by methane gas. There is speculation that this outflow could have been caused by fracking activity in the region.

Source: "Q&A: The challenge of fixing the Hawthorne methane leak". Corey Moore. SCPR. September 19, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.scpr.org/news/2013/09/19/39358/q-a-the-challenge-of-fixing-the-hawthorne-methane/

properties.Name: Nelson Court, Kern County, CA
properties.PopupInfo:
After a Petro Capital Resources Pipeline leak in 2014, resident Francisco Gonzales was not evacuated from his home after a dangerous build-up of toxic gases was discovered in eight homes across the street. He suffered from nosebleeds for months on end and didn't received any financial help from either the company or the county to relocate. Chemicals in the air included toluene, ethyl-benzene and xylene.

Source: "Faces of Fracking". Tara Lohan. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://www.facesoffracking.org/story/gustavo-aguirre-jr/

properties.Name: Kern County
properties.PopupInfo:
Fred Starrh's orchard is near Aera Energy waste disposal pits, which the company decided to leave unlined in order to cut costs. As a result, Starrh's groundwater was contaminated with frack wastewater in 2012. It became so contaminated that it killed every tree in the orchard after a single irrigation, while rendering hundreds of acres barren and unable to sustain life.

Source: "Studies find California 'Fracking' wells may kill livestock, family pets". Dan Aiello. Examiner. January 21, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.examiner.com/article/studies-find-california-fracking-wells-may-kill-livestock-family-pets

Farmer Mike Hopkins sued the California Division of Gas and Geothermal Resources. In 2013 he claimed that the DOGGR illegally allowed Veneco Inc. to drill in his orchards and that high levels of toxic chloride in his groundwater are causing his cherry trees to die.

Source: "Farmers getting fracked: State's No. 1 industry is threatened". Dave Garcia. Chico News & Review. March 14, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.newsreview.com/chico/farmers-getting-fracked/content?oid=9296396

In 2014, state officials allowed oil and gas companies to pump nearly three billion gallons of waste water into underground aquifers that could have been used for drinking water or irrigation. In the state's letter to the EPA, officials admit that in at least nine waste water injection wells that the waste water was injected into clean aquifers containing high-quality water.

Source: "Waste Water from Oil Fracking Injected into Clean Aquifers". Stephen Stock, Liza Meak, Mark Villarreal and Scott Pham. NBC Bay Area. November 14, 2014.
http://www.nbcbayarea.com/investigations/Waste-Water-from-Oil-Fracking-Injected-into-Clean-Aquifers-282733051.html

properties.Name: Bakersfield, Kern County, CA
properties.PopupInfo:
Palla Farms LLC, a 92-year-old family farm, says it had to tear out hundreds of cherry trees due to high levels of salt and boron in the groundwater. The company sued four oil companies -- Crimson Resource Management Corp., Dole Enterprises Inc., E&B Natural Resources Management Corp. and San Joaquin Facilities Management Inc. -- claiming that they violated state environmental regulations when disposing of produced water, drilling mud and flowback water from fracking, which led to the contamination of the ground water.

Source: "California farmers file suit alleging oil companies' faulty wastewater injection caused crop loss". Mike Gaworecki. DeSmogBlog. September 24, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://www.alternet.org/fracking/farmers-file-suit-alleging-oil-companies-wastewater-caused-crop-loss

properties.Name: Inglewood, Los Angeles County
properties.PopupInfo:
Gale Swan, Cheryl Slesthenter, Vivian Harris and John and Alecia Smith live near a Plains Exploration & Production fracking operation. They complain of vibrations that cause cabinets to split from the ceiling, as well as foundation and wall cracks. There is a deep ground fracture on the Smith's property.

Source: "Inglewood Oil Field's neighbors want answers about land shift". Ruben Vives. Los Angeles Times. June 23, 2012. Web. Accessed July 24, 2015.

http://articles.latimes.com/2012/jun/23/local/la-me-inglewood-fracking-20120624

properties.Name: Santa Fe Springs, Los Angeles County
properties.PopupInfo:
A Santa Fe Springs wastewater treatment facility accumulated eight violations caused by hydrogen sulfide gas escaping through holes in aging metal tanks. From January to August 15, the South Coast Air Quality Management District received 460 complaints agaist the facility, with some saying they became nauseous, light-headed and experienced headaches and shortness of breath.

Source: "Ridgeline Energy Services in SFS declared public nuisance but allowed to stay open". Steve Scauzillo. San Gabriel Valley Tribune. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.sgvtribune.com/environment-and-nature/20130820/ridgeline-energy-services-in-sfs-declared-public-nuisance-but-allowed-to-stay-open

properties.Name: West Adams, Los Angeles County
properties.PopupInfo:
Don Martin of Los Angeles County lives near a Freeport McMorRan Oil and Gas facility as of 2013. He reports chemical smells and fumes, and his granddaughter is in remission from Hodgkin's lymphoma. His neighbors have nosebleeds, skin and eye irritation, headaches, and asthma.

Source: "What it's like to have 30 oil & gas wells as neighbors". Tara Lohan. Grist. October 24, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://grist.org/climate-energy/what-its-like-to-have-30-oil-gas-wells-as-neighbors/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_term=Climate%2520Oct%252030&utm_campaign=climate

properties.Name: University Park, Los Angeles
properties.PopupInfo:
Since 2010, 13-year-old Nalleli Cobo and her family have lived across the street from an AllenCo Energy Inc. facility in University Park, an urban oil drilling site. Nalleli has heart problems, gets frequent nosebleeds, headaches and stomach pain. Her mother and grandmother, as well as others in the community, werent' asthmatic until three years ago, around the same time the site opened.

Source: "What happends when a 13-year-old girl takes on an oil company?" Lorraine Chow. NationalSwell. September 18, 2014. Web. Accessed July 10, 2015.
http://nationswell.com/nalleli-cobo-fights-back-against-oil-company/

properties.Name: Oakland, CA
properties.PopupInfo:
A 4-inch natural gas pipeline owned by PG&E erupted and caught fire, burning for hours. Six homes were evacuated, and other residents were told to shelter in place.

Source: "Oakland street on fire after gas line erupts". Chase Cain, Lisa Fernandez and NBC area staff. NBC Bay Area. December 11, 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Oakland-Gas-Line-Erupts-Into-Flames-235249701.html

properties.Name: Ault, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
When a Noble Energy crew was working on an oil and gas tank at an organic farm near Ault, Colorado, a worker failed to open a valve correctly, resulting in a processing equipment backup that caused crude oil to spray across more than 150,000 square feet of an organic farm. The resulting 240 cubic yards of contaminated soil had to be physically scraped from the crop land. It is unsure whether the ground will be fit to grow crops again.

Source: “Spilled released Oil accidents no rarity in Northern Colorado.” Bobby Magill. Windsor Beacon. June 20, 2013.
http://www.coloradoan.com/article/20130621/WINDSORBEACON01/306210023/Spilled-released-Oil-accidents-no-rarity-Northern-Colorado?nclick_check=1

properties.Name: Castle Rock, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Neighbors of the Martinez family began smelling gas around their neighborhood before a natural gas explosion leveled their home with the entire family, including four children, inside. Two additional homes were damaged in the explosion.

Source: “Natural Gas Explosion Destroys Castle Rock Home.” Jordan Steffan. Denver Post. Oct. 12, 2012.
http://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_21757927/natural-gas-explosion-destroys-castle-rock-home-sends#ixzz2IZUd0tFY

properties.Name: Garfield County, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Karen Protz began to feel sick when the fracking boom brought gas wells closer to her log cabin in 2005. Protz, who used to walk five miles a day, now has heart palpitations, sinus infection, benign growths on her thyroid and blood clots. She suffered a mild stroke and feels constantly tired and has trouble catching her breath. She has linked her health problems with the Encana wells near her home.

Source: "Living next to natural gas wells is no fun". Ben Adler. Grist. July 18, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://grist.org/climate-energy/living-next-to-natural-gas-wells-is-no-fun/

properties.Name: Greeley, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
A fracking waste-water injection site went up in flames in April 2015, causing several large explosions. Black smoke spewed for miles and caused the evacuation of three homes.

Source: "Colorado Fracking Wastewater Injection Site up in Flames". Jennifer Baker. Revolution News. April 17, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://revolution-news.com/colorado-fracking-wastewater-injection-site-up-in-flames/                                                                                                             In September 2014, a truck spilled fracking fluid in downtown Greeley, causing fluid to spill from a quarter mile east of 65th Avenue all the way into the intersection of U.S. 34 Bypass and 65th Avenue. The truck was marked with the logo Clear Water Products, a company that provides a variety of services to the oil and gas industry.

Source: "Fracking fluid spill backs up Greeley traffic for hours". Tyler Silvy. Greeley Tribune. September 13, 2014.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5D4G-MJP1-DYNS-30R4&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Longmont, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Rod Brueske moved to the outskirts of Longmont to restore a 1904 farmstead and raise his family on an organic farm, but Encana built a drill pad across the street in January of 2012. The family experienced vibrations, nosebleeds, and gastrointestinal problems. Brueske was forced to move his family to a hotel.

Source: "Farmer irked by leaky gas well near home seeks bigger fine for Encana". Bruce Finley. The Denver Post. November 15, 2012. Web. Accessed July 30, 2015.
http://www.denverpost.com/ci_22005614/farmer-irked-by-leaky-gas-well-near-home

properties.Name: Dolores County, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Earl Wenger and Cindy Tout live less than 300 yards from a Kinder Morgan compressor station that was installed in 2008. Since then they have experienced non-stop noise and a sulfur and bleach smell in the air. They have also had frequent headaches, nosebleeds, and sore throats, and their home has been damaged from the vibration.

Source: "Is Kinder Morgan a good neighbor?". Gail Binkly. Four Corners Free Press. May 1, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://fourcornersfreepress.com/?p=550

properties.Name: North of Parachute, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Shane Hill, a 34-year old man working on a WPX Energy rig north of Parachute was fatally struck on the back of the head with a high-pressure gate valve in October 2014. He was thrown about six feet from the pipe.

Source: "Report released on fatal drilling rig accident". Associated Press. NBC 11 News. October 31, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://www.nbc11news.com/home/headlines/Report-released-on-fatal-drilling-rig-accident-281069332.html

properties.Name: Fort Lupton, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
Near Fort Lupton, Colorado, a ruptured pipe left one worker dead and two others seriously injured in November of 2014. The Haliburton workers were attempting to warm a frozen pipe when the accident occurred. The Andarko Petroleum Corps site and surrounding fracking pads were shut down at the time for safety reasons.

Source: “Fracking accident leaves 1 dead, 2 injured in Colorado” James Queally. La-Times. November 13, 2014. Accessed January 10, 2017.
http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-fracking-accident-colorado-20141113-story.html

Brian Wallace, 60, was killed in a natural gas well explosion near Fort Lupton in August 2012. He died from multiple blunt force injuries that occurred when pressurized gas was released as workers prepared one of three wells on Encana Corp.'s Davis well pad to begin pumping.

Source: "Man killed in natural gas well explosion near Fort Lupton identified". Yesenia Robles. The Denver Post. August 17, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_21332352/man-killed-natural-gas-well-explosion-near-fort

properties.Name: Fort Collins, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2013, fracking fluid gushed from an oil well near Fort Collins for almost 30 hours before it was stopped. A piece of equipment fell onto a valve and broke it, causing the oil-laden fluid to rush out. Observers said the liquid was tinted green.

Source: "Workers stop fracking-fluid leak after 30 hours". Fort Collins Coloradoan. February 12, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.9news.com/story/local/2013/02/12/1839862/

properties.Name: Greeley, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2014, two workers were injured in an explosion and fire at an oil and gas drilling site north of the town of Greeley. The explosion occurred as workers were pulling an oil and water mixture out of storage tanks to take to a separator. Firefighters believe that static electricity could have set off the vapors. According to onlookers, the explosion shook houses and set a fire that could be seen for miles.

Source: "Greeley, Colorading Gas Drilling Site Explosion may have been Caused by Static Electricity". Associated Press. Huffington Post. March 4, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/04/greeley-colorado-gas-explosion_n_4898525.html?utm_hp_ref=green

properties.Name: Weld County, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
One worker was killed and two injured when a Halliburton high-pressure waterline ruptured in November of 2014. The workers were thawing the frozen waterline when a pressurized stream of fracking fluid killed one worker on impact. Halliburton halted all fracking activity at the site until a review of the accident was completed.

Source: “Fracking blast kills one Halliburton worker, injures 2 in Weld County”. Jesse Paul and Mark Jaffe. The Denver Post. November 13, 2014
http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_26930029/one-dead-following-fracking-accident-weld-county                                                                                                                                                                         Angela Waldrop and family have experienced round the clock noise and vibration from an Encana Corp. well 700 feet away from their house. "The noise was like a high-power generator, but it was the vibrations that really took a toll", said Waldrop.

Source: "Drilling rigs and housing develoment face off in Colorado suburbs". Mark Jaffe. The Denver Post. February 13, 2015. Web. Accessed July 2, 2015.
http://www.denverpost.com/managingtheboom/ci_27522307/drilling-rigs-and-housing-development-face-off-colorado

Jim Freemyer died in Weld County, CO in July 2014 from inhaling a toxic mix of chemicals. He was wearing a protective mask while measuring oil levels after opening a tank hatch when he was found by a coworker. He is one of nine oil workers found to have died this way since 2010.

Source: "Colorado judge awards benefits from Weld County oil patch death." Monete Whaley. The Denver Post. July 29, 2015. Accessed October 30, 2015. http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_28552933/colorado-judge-awards-benefits-from-oil-patch-death

properties.Name: Erie, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
A 26-year-old man from Brighton was killed in an explosion, and another person was injured in January 2015. Investigators believe that he was using a welding torch near a vacuum tank trailer that was previously used to haul crude oil from well sites. It's believed that the spark from the torch ignited residual oil inside or outside of the tank.

Source: "1 man killed, another injured in explosion". Associated Press. NBC 9 News. January 14, 2015.
http://www.9news.com/story/news/local/2015/01/14/1-man-killed-another-injured-in-explosion-east-of-erie/21789395/

properties.Name: Windsor, CO
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2013, fracking fluid with oil in it gushed from an oil well at a PDC Energy site in Windsor, Colorado for over thirty hours after a piece of equipment broke a hydraulic valve. The spill was one of multiple PDC Energy spills on record that year.

Source: “Oil well leaks ‘frac’ water for 30 hours in Weld County.” David Mitchell. Fox 31 – Denver. February 12, 2013.
http://kdvr.com/2013/02/12/oil-well-leaks-frac-water-for-30-hours-in-weld-county/

properties.Name: Dixie, LA
properties.PopupInfo:
A family who lives near a natural gas drilling site discovered that their tap water was flammable. The Parker family has two houses that share a private well, and they had been having problems with their water pressure and air in the pipes for about a year before they discovered the water was flammable. In addition, their 17-year-old daughter passed out while doing dishes.

"Dixie, LA family finds their tap water is flammable". Victoria Shirley. KSLA News. December 2, 2013. Web. Accessed July 17, 2015.
http://www.ksla.com/story/24116649/dixie-family-finds-their-tap-water-is-flammable

properties.Name: Geismar, LA
properties.PopupInfo:
An explosion at Williams Partners LP's petrochemical plant destroyed much of the facility, killed two workers and injured more than 80 people in June 2013. The explosion was caused by a rupture in a reboiler.

Source: An explosion at Williams Partners LP's petrochemical plant destroyed much of the facility, killed two workers and injured more than 80 people. The explosion was caused by a rupture in a reboiler.
http://www.tulsaworld.com/business/energy/tulsa-based-williams-partners-has-restarted-louisiana-plant-damaged-in/article_3c219c9d-d7ae-52a6-a5a7-cd8762dd2897.html

properties.Name: St. Landry Parish, LA
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2014, a natural gas pipeline owned by Enlink Midstream company ruptured, causing the evacuation of residents within a two-mile radius.

Source: "Officials in St. Landry say the air is clear following pipeline rupture". Dave Fields. KATC. March 13, 2014.
http://linux.synapse-cms.com/news/officials-in-st-landry-says-the-air-is-clear-following-pipeline-rupture/

properties.Name: Berrien County, MI
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, a gas pipeline owned by TransCanada ruptured, causing more than 500 people to be evacuated from their homes. Farmer Vic Rogers said that TransCanada advised him that his three acres of potatoes around the explosion may be contaminated and should not be harvested.

Source: "Evacuation order over pipeline rupture in Berrien County". WSBT TV. September 16, 2014. Web. Accessed July 10, 2015.
http://www.wsbt.com/news/local/breaking-evacuations-after-massive-gas-line-rupture-in-benton-twp/28079504

properties.Name: Jackson County, MI
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2013, truck driver Greg Peacock struck and ruptured a natural gas pipeline at an East Bay Exploration oil well on Dorrell Road, causing gas to emit into the open air. When Peacock went to turn the gas valve off, his truck's engine ignited the cloud, and he was critically injured.

Source: "Explosion in Leoni Township: Man severely burned and in critical condition after truck strikes gas pipeline, investigation ongoing". Will Forgrave. Mlive. June 17, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.mlive.com/news/jackson/index.ssf/2013/06/explosion_in_leoni_township_ma.html

properties.Name: Kalkaska County
properties.PopupInfo:
Between May 15 and June 13 2012, 40,000 gallons of Encana produced water was spread on roads to control dust. This water, leftover from fracking operations, was thought to pose a threat to groundwater and wildlife.

Source: "Fracked Roads: Activists angered over flowback wastewater being sprayed on roads". Patrick Sullivan. Nothern Express. October 1, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.northernexpress.com/michigan/article-5927-fracked-roads.html

properties.Name: Carnes, MS
properties.PopupInfo:
In 2009, two local Mississippi teens were killed when a natural gas tank at a well production site exploded. According to local teens, the site was a popular hangout, and the teens' parents say that the deaths could have been prevented if some warning signs had been posted.

Source: "Fatal gas tank blast brings calls for better warnings". Susan Candiotti and Ross Levitt. CNN. April 11, 2010.
http://www.cnn.com/2010/US/04/11/gas.tank.safety/index.html?iref=allsearch

properties.Name: Rankin County, MS
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, a 30-inch Gulf South natural gas pipeline ruptured and exploded, scorching at least an acre of land off Three Prong trail. Gas was cut off to at least 25 customers, and an observer said that it "felt like an atomic bomb or something had gone off".

Source: "'It was like an atomic bomb went off': Neighbors describe pipeline explosion". Cheryl Lasseter. MS Newsroom NOW. January 14, 2015. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://www.msnewsnow.com/story/27851155/it-was-like-an-atomic-bomb-went-off-neighbors-describe-pipeline-explosion

properties.Name: Dawson County, MT
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, a rupture in the Poplar pipeline, which transports crude oil from Montana and North Dakota, spilled up to 50,000 gallons of Bakken shale crude oil into the Yellowstone River. Local residents worried that their water supplies had been contaminated, and the extent of environmental damage is unknown.

Source: "Washington: Ruptured Pipeline Pumps Tens of Thousands of Gallons of Shale Oil Along Yellowstone River". Plus Media Solutions. January 20, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5FW4-1XB1-DXCW-D2TG&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: East of Willard, MT
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2013, a pipeline owned by Denbury Onshore leaked, releasing 17,000 barrels of saltwater brine from oil wells. The leak reached the Big Gumbo Creek, which is approximately 14 miles south of Marmarth, North Dakota.

Source: "Saltwater from breached Montana pipeline reaches North Dakota". Lauren Donovan. The Bismarck Tribune, November 27, 2013. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2014.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=59XN-J8K1-F039-F0YK&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Lambert, MT
properties.PopupInfo:
30-year-old Trent Vigus suffered a "cardiac event" in July 2010 after being exposed to chemical fumes while cleaning an XTO Energy Inc. Eugene 14X-8 well. He climbed a set of steel stairs to gather readings from the top of the tanks, and his co-workers found him in a fetal position on the catwalk. They carried him down and frantically tried CPR, with no reponse. Laboratory tests found small amounts of propane and butane in his blood. These chemicals are found in Bakken crude. Even though Vigus's death was called a cardiac event, he had no hardening of the arteries that is associated with heart disease.

Source: Poisoned by the shale? Investigations leave questions in oil tank deaths. Mike Soraghan. EnergyWire. October 27, 2014.
http://www.eenews.net/special_reports/danger_zone/stories/1060007896

properties.Name: Branchburg, NJ
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2013, a flash fire at a natural gas pipeline compression facility, Transco Pipeline, sent two construction workers to local hospitals and caused minor injuries to 13 other workers. Three emergency fire crews were needed to extinguish the fire.

Source: “Multiple injuries reported at Branchburg gas pipeline facility flash fire.” Walter O’Brien. NJ.com. May 30, 2013
http://www.nj.com/somerset/index.ssf/2013/05/multiple_injuries_reported_at.html

properties.Name: Lea/Eddy County, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2014, an explosion at an oil field tank battery on the Lea/Eddy county line left two workers injured. The source of the explosion is believed to have been caused by a tank battery fire. Black smoke could be seen billowing from the location while driving down the Hobbs Highway.

Source: "2 reported injured in oil field explosion on county line". Sarah Matott. Carlsbad Current-Argus, N.M. November 30, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://bakken.com/news/id/226721/2-reported-injured-oil-field-explosion-county-line/

properties.Name: Sandoval County, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2013, a hydraulic fracking operation by Encana Oil & Gas Inc. affected a Parko Oil well, causing a spill of 200 barrels of oil and fracking fluid. Only 75 barrels of oil were recovered.

Source: "Hydraulic Fracturing: Small fortune is lost when oil giant's well collides with family business". Gayathri Vaidyanathan. EnergyWire. October 24, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.eenews.net/stories/1059989314

properties.Name: Carlsbad, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2012, two men were burned in an explosion at a well site southeast of Carlsbad. They were employed by Air Tech Drilling. When responders arrived, two tanks partially filled with oil and two foam injection trailers were on fire. Medical helicopters were called to take the victims to the hospital.

Source: "Two burned in well explosion southeast of Carlsbad". Current Argus. November 10, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.currentargus.com/ci_21968433/two-burned-well-explosion-southeast-carlsbad

properties.Name: Carlsbad, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2012, a natural gas pipeline explosion left a crater 86 feet wide and caused a fire lasting nearly 40 minutes and visible from twenty miles – the explosion killed five adults and five children who were camping less than 300 yards from the site, leaving two others in critical condition. Authorities said the ruptured line became a virtual flame-thrower, showering fire on the victims. The pipe was run by El Paso Natural Gas Co.

Source: “Pipeline Explosion Kills 10 Campers in N.M.” ABC News. August 20, 2012.
http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=96090&page=1#.UcSlCPnvtnY

properties.Name: Eddy County, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2014, a worker was killed in a pipeline explosion at 730 W. Kincaid Ranch Road. A team of mean employed by Diversified Oil Field Services was working in a pit to cut pipeline and capping lines at the time of the explosions, and three of the four men working in the pit were able to escape. The fourth, Fabian Martinez, 21, is believed to have been pinned by pipes , and died after inhaling H2S gas released in the explosion.

Source: "Pipe explosion near Artesia leaves one man dead". Jessica Onsurez. Current-Argus News. July 31, 2014. Web. Accessed July 10, 2015.
http://www.currentargus.com/carlsbad-news/ci_26251977/pipe-explosion-artesia-leaves-one-man-dead

properties.Name: Delaware County, NY
properties.PopupInfo:
After an accident at a Millennium Pipeline natural gas compression station, a family on Hungry hill in the town of Hancock was forced to evacuate their home for the night in December 2013. The station had been under construction since October, and was being built to increase pressure and gas output on the Millennium Pipeline, which reaches across New York State's Southern Tier from Steuben County to Rockland County. According to a company spokesman, workers on the site were connecting another line to the main line when something went awry, forcing the workers to vent millions of gallons of gas from a 10-mile long stretch of the 30-inch pipeline.

Source: "Hancock family evacuates after pipeline accident". Lissa Harris. Watershed Post. December 9, 2013. Web. Accessed July 17, 2015.
http://www.watershedpost.com/2013/hancock-family-evacuates-after-pipeline-accident

properties.Name: Alexander, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2013, an explosion ignited 13 tanks and spilled 2,700 barrels of salt water and oil southwest of Alexander.

Source: "Life in the boom". Curt Brown. Star Tribune (Mpls. - St. Paul). November 30, 2013.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?oc=00240&hnsd=f&hgn=t&lni=59YV-28V1-DYRH-930Y&hns=t&perma=true&hv=t&hl=t&csi=270944%2C270077%2C11059%2C8411&secondRedirectIndicator=true

Also, in February 2014 approximately 250 barrels of brine spilled at an oil well site owned by RIM Operating Inc., three miles west of Alexander. The salt water came through the berm, a protective barrier, and ran into an iced-over drainage, which is a tributary to Lonesome Creek.

Source: "Alexander well site spills 250 barrels of salt water". Jessica Holdman. The Bismarck Tribune, February 11, 2014. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5BGW-4CK1-F039-F522&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Antler, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In a remote section of farm country in Bottineau county, landowner Mike Artz and his two neighbors discovered that a ruptured pipeline was spewing contaminated wastewater into his crop fields. In August 2013, state testing of the wetlands showed that chloride levels were so high they exceeded the range of the test strips. The North Dakota Department of Health estimated that between 400 to 600 barrels of wastewater, the equivalent of 16,800 to 25,200 gallons, had seeped into the ground.

Source: "In shadow of oil boom, North Dakota farmers fight contamination". Laura Gottesdiener. Aljazeera America. September 6, 2014.
http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2014/9/6/north-dakota-wastewaterlegacy.html

properties.Name: Arnegard, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2011, a fire started in an oil well while the well was being fracture treated, causing fracking fluids, a plume of natural gas and crude oil to escape from the well and ignite. Heavy snow around the fire was coated with a thick yellow residue, partly a crude oil mist, and officials said cleanup could entail a containment dike or moving the snow to a disposal location.

Source: "Oil fire keeps burning". Lauren Donovan. Bismarck Tribune. March 9, 2011.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=52BT-FS11-F039-F4H5&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Belfield, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2014, a well site owned by Slawson Exploration Co. leaked an estimated 350 barrels of brine from a tank about 10 miles northwest of Belfield. The company did not report the leak until a week after it had occurred.

Source: "350-barrel brine spill reported near Belfield". The Dickinson Press, N.D. September 5, 2014. LexisNexus Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/hottopics/lnacademic/?

properties.Name: Bowman County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, 2,000 barrels of source water, used for enhanced oil recovery, spilled from the Paynter Source Well owned by Denbury Onshore LLC as a result of a leak in the pipeline. The water flowed into a nearby creek and could not be recovered. Source water is higher in dissolved solids and minerals than fresh water.

Source: "FROM THE OIL FIELDS: Source water leaks from pipeline south of Marmarth". Bryce Martin. Bownman County Pioneer. September 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.bowmanextra.com/2014/09/12/oil-fields-source-water-leaks-pipeline-south-marmarth/

properties.Name: Burke County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2013, Coby A Thibodeaux was killed at an Oasis Petroleum drill site after a payloader backed over him.

Source: "Man killed in drillsite incident". Kathrine Schmidt. Upstream. May 30, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article1328492.ece

properties.Name: Bowbells, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
An oilfield spill involving equipment owned by OXY USA Inc. released contamination into a tributary of Stony Creek about 10 miles southwest of Bowbells in March of 2015. Equipment malfunction caused brine and oil to spray off the location, spilling about 60 barrels of brine and five barrels of oil.

Source: "Oilfield spill affect tributary in Burke County". Forum News Service. The Dickinson Press. March 13, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://www.thedickinsonpress.com/news/north-dakota/3699638-oilfield-spill-affects-tributary-burke-county

properties.Name: Cass County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2013, a mile-long train carrying crude oil collided with another train, triggering a series of explosions and sending toxic fumes into the air. A train carrying grain derailed first, and then knocked several cars of the crude oil train off adjoining tracks. A mushroom cloud of fire blasted into the sky and then black smoke covered the surrounding area. The flames created dark clouds that could be seen for miles. This explosion was the third accident in six months involving trains transporting North Dakota crude oil.

Source: "Casselton, ND, Evacuation Order Lifted after Fiery Train Collision". Anthony Castellano and Alex Perez. Good Morning America. December 31 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
https://gma.yahoo.com/casselton-n-d-residents-urged-evacuate-oil-train-122129693--abc-news-topstories.html

properties.Name: Crosby, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2014, a brine spill occurred at a well site owned by Samson Resources Co. six miles southwest of Crosby. A valve leak caused a spray of brine; approximately 410 barrels were contained on the site and 15 barrels escaped onto cultivated land.

Source: The Bismarck Tribune, May 30, 2014. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5C9W-TSC1-JCM7-R3F5&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Dunn County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2012, a 21-year-old Montana man died of hydrocarbon poisoning at a Marathon Oil well site. He inhaled petroleum vapors while working.

Source: "Hydrocarbon poisoning blamed for N.D. oil worker death". Jessica Holdman. Bismarck Tribune. July 5, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://bismarcktribune.com/bakken/hydrocarbon-poisoning-blamed-for-n-d-oil-worker-death/article_71b31cc6-c716-11e1-88e1-001a4bcf887a.html

properties.Name: Dickinson, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2013, a leak in an underground line sent 150 barrels of disposed salt water leaching into U.S. Forest Service land west of Dickinson.

Source: "Life in the boom". Curt Brown. Star Tribune (Mpls. - St. Paul). November 30, 2013.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?oc=00240&hnsd=f&hgn=t&lni=59YV-28V1-DYRH-930Y&hns=t&perma=true&hv=t&hl=t&csi=270944%2C270077%2C11059%2C8411&secondRedirectIndicator=true

properties.Name: Dickinson, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2014, a pipeline near a well pad owned by C12 Energy leaked, causing approximately 148 barrels of brine and two barrels of oil to flow off the well pad and through a ditch onto newly annexed land on the north side of Dickinson.

Source: "Brine, oil spill reported north of Dickinson". Dakota Wire, The Bismarck Tribune. February 28, 2014.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5BV7-YYR1-JCM7-R2WP&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Lake Sakakawea, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2012, a Slawson Exploration Co. well near Lake Sakakawea spilled about 1,500 barrels of oils, gas and salt water into the surrounding area.

Source: "Oil well blowout controlled near Watford City". Lauren Donovan. The Bismarck Tribune, December 24, 2012. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=56CX-JX31-DYNS-31V3&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Montrail County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A worker was critically injured in an explosion at a Frontier drilling rig in September 2012. He was severely burned when a tank exploded. He was taken off life support when it was discovered that his injuries were far more extensive than was originally thought.

Source: "Man burned in N.D. oil rig explosion pronounced dead". Stephanie Grimes. KSL. September 14, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=22140458

properties.Name: McKenzie County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2012, an explosion at an oil well site between Alexander and Arnedgard severely burned two men. Bruce Ford, 52, and Rod Law, 48, were working at the well site during the explosion, and had to be transported by air ambulance to a burn center in St. Paul, Minn. The men were working on a well tank that contained gas fumes, and those fumes were somehow ignited, causing the explosion.

Source: "Explosion injures two at oil well site". Kate Ruggles. McKenzie County Farmer. August 29, 2012. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.watfordcitynd.com/?id=10&nid=1793

properties.Name: Watford City, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2016, one worker died and three others received injuries in a fire at a Mckenzie County oil well around 8 miles east of Watford City. Two of the injured workers received 3rd degree burns on over 70 percent of their bodies. The crew was working at a fracking well owned by XTO, a subsidiary of ExxonMobil. The worker’s employer, Most Wanted Well Service, received a fine of $2,800 for a violation in november 2015.

Source: "Oil worker killed in fire, 3 others injured." Amy Dalrymple. The Bismarck Tribune. June 20, 2016. Accessed January 3, 2017. http://bismarcktribune.com/bakken/oil-worker-killed-in-fire-others-injured/article_0871acd6-2506-57b5-9500-81f07a22ffc0.htmlIn

March 2014, one man was injured when a Nabors production rig caught fire near Watford City. The rig was on a Whiting Petroleum site. The initial cause of the fire is believed to be a pressure build up that caused material to escape and ignite.

Source: "Oil rig explodes near Watford City". Jerry Burnes. Williston Herald. March 26, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.willistonherald.com/news/oil-rig-explodes-near-watford-city/article_1c0cf71e-b4eb-11e3-88c4-001a4bcf887a.html In January 2013, one worker was killed in an incident at a Halliburton North Dakota hydraulic fracturing facility. The victim, a 49-year-old Air Force veteran, died on site after a pipe, disconnected by increased pressure, struck him in the head. Other workers were hospitalized with injuries.

Source: “Minnesota Man Dies in ND Hydraulic Fracturing Accident.” Associated Press. January 21, 2013.
http://www.twincities.com/allheadlines/ci_22417840/minnesota-man-dies-nd-hydraulic-fracturing-accident/ In December 2012 a blowout occurred at an oil well owned by Newfield Exploration Co., spewing a geyser of oil, gas and salt water 95 feet into the air and spreading contamination more than a mile downwind from the well site.

Source: "Oil well blowout controlled near Watford City". Lauren Donovan. The Bismarck Tribune, December 24, 2012. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=56CX-JX31-DYNS-31V3&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: McKenzie County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A corroded pipe at a well owned by Oasis Petroleum leaked 1,000 barrels of brine. According to the North Dakota Department of Health, an unknown amount of brine made its way into a nearby stream.

Source: "Pipe leaks 1,000 barrels of brine". The Bismarck Tribune, October 10, 2014. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5DBW-1741-F039-F1Y8&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Renville County, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, an estimated 25 barrels of oil and 820 barrels of brine (a byproduct of hydraulic fracturing that often contains heavy concentrations of salts, heavy metals and radioactive material) were spilled at an oil well site in Renville County.

Source: "Spill reported in Renville County". The Dickinson Press, N.D. January 15, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5F2Y-7H91-JC6P-C209&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: South of Tioga, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2014, an explosion and fireball occurred at a Hiland Partners compressor station south of Tioga, which rattled windows as far as 30 miles away.

Source: "Bakken Briefly - Feb. 26, 2014: Plant explosion raises questions". The Tioga Tribune. February 25, 2014. Web. Accessed July 15, 2015.
http://bismarcktribune.com/bakken/bakken-briefly---feb/article_f6d8de7a-9ea8-11e3-ba20-001a4bcf887a.html

properties.Name: Tioga, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2014, the wellhead of a fracking site failed, causing leakage of oil, gas, and fracking fluid. The well, owned by Emerald Oil, continued to leak for days after the problem was identified. Tests taken at the site showed hydrogen sulfide levels at 20 parts per million.

Source: “North Dakota Oil Well Still Leaking Crude, Gas And Fracking Fluid Days After Spill”. Josh Wood. Huffington Post. May 13 2014.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/13/north-dakota-oil-well_n_5317000.html

properties.Name: Northwest of Tioga, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
At a site 12 miles northwest of Tioga, about 500 barrels of brine spilled in February 2015. A portion escaped the site, and according to health officials it impacted a nearby wetland. A second spill occurred about 15 miles northwest of Tioga, and involved about 460 barrels of brine. Health officials say that this spill may also impact nearby wetlands.

Source: "Five significant oil-related spills reported over weekend in N.D." Amy Dalrymple. Grand Forks Herald. February 17, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://www.grandforksherald.com/news/region/3681616-five-significant-oil-related-spills-reported-over-weekend-nd

properties.Name: Watford City, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
An oil well blowout caused 15 workers to flee for safety in February 2014. The accident occurred after a piece of equipment failed at a well about seven miles north from the Theodore Roosevelt National Park. The initial blowout sprayed a mist of oil and water onto snow lying on top of the ice-covered Cherry Creek. The company that operates the site, Whiting Oil and Gas, said that about 50 barrels of flowback water were released but contained on site within a berm. Hydraulic fracturing had been completed on the well and the fluid that was released was the water-based solution that flows back to the surface.

Source: "Equipment failure causes Whiting oil well blowout: Workers flee from stie near Watford City". Amy Dalrymple. The Dickinson Press. February 15, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.thedickinsonpress.com/content/equipment-failure-causes-whiting-oil-well-blowout-workers-flee-site-near-watford-city

properties.Name: Fort Berthold Reservation, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
More than a million gallons of salty drilling waste spilled from a pipeline onto a steep hillside in western North Dakota in July 2014. The waste was a byproduct of oil and gas production. It contaminated a tributary of Lake Sakakawea, which provides drinking water to a nearby reservation. The spill killed vegetation and contaminated the soil.

Source: "Saltwater' from Fracking Spill is not What's Found in the Ocean." Lisa Song. Bloomberg Business. July 16, 2014.
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-07-16/-saltwater-from-fracking-spill-is-not-what-s-found-in-the-ocean.html

properties.Name: Mandaree, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A pipeline owned by Arrow Water LLC leaked 3,000 barrels of brine near the town of Mandaree in September 2014. This was the second such incident at the reservation by the same company in two months.

Source: "Second Frack Waste Leak in Two Months on Fort Berthold Reservation". Plus Media Solutions, US Official News. September 3, 2014.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5BBH-T3V1-J9XT-P04G&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Heimdal, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
Cars from a BNSF railway train carrying crude oil obtained from the Bakken shale derailed and caught fire, resulting in the evacuation of 40 town residents in May 2015.

Source: "Federal Investigators Look for Cause of Fiery North Dakota Train Crash". Dave Aeikens. ABC News. May 6, 2015. Accessed July 1, 2015.
http://kstp.com/news/stories/s3787863.shtml

properties.Name: White Earth, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A spill at an Oasis Petroleum site 11 miles northeast of White Earth released at least 500 barrels of water (used for hydraulic fracturing) and three barrels of oil in September 2014.

Source: "ND energy workers contain oil, water spill". The Bismarck Tribune, September 17, 2014. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5D5B-JVB1-JCM7-R2D8&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Wildrose, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A brine spill occurred when a valve or piping connection leaked approximately 200 barrels of brine from a Crescent Point Energy well two miles west of Wildrose in May 2014. The spill impacted cultivated land; approximately 80 barrels were recovered and the impacted soil was removed to a licensed disposal facility.

Source: The Bismarck Tribune, May 30, 2014. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=5C9W-TSC1-JCM7-R3F5&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: South of Williston, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
Zachary Buckles, a 20-year-old from Glasgow, Montana was found dead with his head over a tank hatch at a Continental Resources Inc. well site south of Williston, N.D. in April 2014. He was working for a small contractor called Black Gold Testing. Petroleum poisoning is suspected as a cause of death.

Source: Poisoned by the shale? Investigations leave questions in oil tank deaths. Mike Soraghan. EnergyWire. October 27, 2014.
http://www.eenews.net/special_reports/danger_zone/stories/1060007896

properties.Name: North of Williston, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
About 1,240 barrels of saltwater were released after a drain valve was left open on a pipeline in November 2013. Eric Bayes of Oasis Petroleum said an employee discovered a large puddle at a well site north of Williston.

Source: "Cleanup underway after Williston saltwater pipeline spill". Amy Dalrymple. Oil Patch Dispatch. November 12, 2013. Web. Accessed July 17, 2015.
http://oilpatchdispatch.areavoices.com/2013/11/12/cleanup-underway-after-williston-saltwater-pipeline-spill/

properties.Name: Watford City, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
Deep Creek Federal 43X-5D well, southeast of Watford City, ND, blew out on August 29, 2015. It leaked 550 barrels (23,100 gallons) of crude onto the pad and surrounding grasses. The well was being fracked when its pressure control valves failed, resulting in the oil leak in addition to 4,620 gallons of leaked saltwater. The well is owned by XTO Energy, a subsidiary of Exxon Mobil.

Source: "XTO Energy well in North Dakota suffers blowout, leaks 550 barrels" Ernest Scheyder, Reuters. August 31, 2015. Accessed October 29, 2015. http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/31/us-exxon-mobil-leak-idUSKCN0R021Q20150831

properties.Name: Williston, ND
properties.PopupInfo:
A pipeline leak that began January 6, 2015 spilled more than three million gallons of brine, a byproduct of hydraulic fracturing that is considered toxic because it is saltier than seawater and often contains other fracking fluids and petroleum. The leak reached the Missouri River, and is the largest saltwater spill in the state's history.

Source: "Fracking brine leak in North Dakota reaches Missouri River, prompts state Democrats to call for more regulation". Rebecca Jacobson. PBS Newshour. January 26, 2015.
http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/fracking-brine-leak-north-dakota-reaches-missouri-river-prompts-state-democrats-call-regulation/

Also, in August 2012 an oil well blowout sprayed 400 barrels of oil and 400 barrels of produced water used for hydraulic fracturing. Crews had completed the drilling and hydraulic fracturing process for that well and were completing the well for production when the blowout occurred.

Source: "Crews clean at oil well blowout site near Williston". Amy Dalrymple. The Dickinson Press, N.D. August 20, 2012. LexisNexis Academic. Web. Accessed June 30, 2015.
http://www.lexisnexis.com.proxy.lib.duke.edu/lnacui2api/api/version1/getDocCui?lni=56CX-JX31-DYNS-31V3&csi=270944,270077,11059,8411&hl=t&hv=t&hnsd=f&hns=t&hgn=t&oc=00240&perma=true

properties.Name: Belmont County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
David Zamora, 43, died during an accident at a natural gas facility in Smith township in April 2014. He was crushed to death by a piece of heavy equipment at the Rice Energy Big Foot Pad.

Source: "Texas gas worker killed in accident in Belmont County". Associated Press. CantonRep. April 8, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.cantonrep.com/article/20140408/News/140409320#ixzz30rKiG6xE

properties.Name: Bloomingdale, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
400 families were evacuated from their homes after a fracking well ruptured in October 2014, leaking natural gas and methane into the air. The families returned to their homes two days later when the well was shut down for repairs.

Source: “Most allowed back home after fracking-well blowout in eastern Ohio” http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/10/29/well_explosion.html Laura Arenschield. The Columbus Dispatch. October 30, 2014.
http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/10/29/well_explosion.html

properties.Name: Bolivar, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
Paul Christopher Sherman, 19, was killed in an oil and natural gas explosion off state Route 212 in Wilshire Hills. Sherman was doing touchup painting in at the well site when it exploded in July 2012.

Source: "Jackson man killed in Bolivar blast". Joe Mizer. Canton Rep. July 17, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.cantonrep.com/x1062476617/Canton-area-man-died-in-Bolivar-blast

properties.Name: Lee Township, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
James Masterson, 54, was killed in a one-vehicle crash in Lee Township in April 2013. He was driving a 2012 Freightline and lost control when navigating a right curve. The vehicle overturned and went off the left side of the road. Masterson was hauling 44,000 pounds of frac sand in conjunction with the oil and gas exploration industry.

Source: "Troopers release name of truck driver killed in Carroll County crash". Times Reporter. April 24, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.timesreporter.com/article/20130424/NEWS/304249840

properties.Name: Carroll County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2013, a tanker caught fire at a gas well site off Brussel road, creating a fire that lasted more than 15 hours. The truck ignited at the well site during a routine transfer of condensate, a liquid petroleum product from the well. The fire started at the transfer point into the tanker, and spread to two holding tanks for condensate.

Source: "Well-site fire in Carroll County extinguished". Nancy Schaar. Times Reporter. September 28, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.timesreporter.com/x511630323/Well-fire-in-Carroll-County-extinguished?zc_p=1

In February 2012, a man was killed on the R.E. Gas Development drilling site in Carol county after a piece of equipment swung and hit him on the back. Another man was injured in the incident, suffering a cut to the back of his head when he fell backwards on the platform.

Source: “One Man Dead, One Injured after Drilling Accident.” WTOV 9. Feb. 26, 2013.
http://www.wtov9.com/news/news/one-man-dead-one-injured-after-drilling-accident/nWZfS/

properties.Name: 160 miles east of Columbus, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In a town 160 miles east of Columbus, 25 families had to evacuate their homes due to an uncontrollable gas leak from a fracking well in December 2014. The families were unable to return to their homes for at least three days.

Source: “Families flee out-of-control natural-gas leak at eastern Ohio fracking well” http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/12/17/families-flee-out-of-control-natural-gas-leak.html. Laura Arenschield. The Columbus Dispatch. December 17, 2014.
http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/12/17/families-flee-out-of-control-natural-gas-leak.html

properties.Name: Coshocton County
properties.PopupInfo:
John Robers, 27, was working on an oil rig when he fell about 50 feet from a platform and died in August 2013. He sustained serious injuries from the fall and was pronounced dead at the scene.

Source: "Man dies after fall from oil platform". Coshocton Tribune. August 16, 2013. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.coshoctontribune.com/article/20130815/NEWS01/308150004/Man-dies-after-fall-from-oil-rig?sf16112449=1&nclick_check=1

properties.Name: Guernsey County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
One person was killed and four others injured after a gas leak at a well in Guernsey County in September 2009. Officials said the men were working on a gas rig, preparing to cap the well, when they were overtaken by a poisonous hydrogen-sulfide gas mixture. The gas the men encountered is commonly referred to as “poison gas” or “sour gas” and is common in natural gas drilling.

Source: “1 killed, 4 wounded in gas well accident.” WTOV 9. Sept. 10, 2009.
http://www.wtov9.com/news/news/1-killed-4-wounded-in-gas-well-accident/nJNXb/

properties.Name: Lorain County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
Staff and students of Admiral Ernest J. King Elementary School had to evacuate their school for more than three months due to a natural gas leak from an old well. The evacuation lasted from October 2014 to January 2015.

Source: "Families visist Admiral King Elementary after long evacuation". Carol Harper. The Morning Journal. December 31, 2014. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://www.morningjournal.com/general-news/20141231/families-visit-admiral-king-elementary-after-long-evacuation

properties.Name: Sardis, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2014, a gas well pad leak caused 30 homes in a 1.5 mile radius to be evacuated in the town of Sardis. The well pad was a Stadler 3UH, owned by Triad Hunter LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Magnum Hunter Resources Corp, off OH Rt. 255.

Source: "EMA: Operations at Well 'Proceeding as Planned'". WTRF 7 News. December 13, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.wtrf.com/story/27622762/homes-evacuated-in-sardis-due-to-gas-leak

properties.Name: Beallsville, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2014, an underground pipeline carrying fracking fluid exploded, setting fire to several acres of woods. Local residents say the explosion emitted flames several hundred feet high and the blast could be felt in their homes. No one was injured.

Source: “Monroe County Pipeline Fire Scene Cleared; Investigation Continues”
http://www.wtrf.com/story/27055643/crews-responding-to-pipeline-explosion-on-mellotts-ridge-monroe-county. Rachael Dierkes. WTRF.com 7 News. Posted: Oct 28, 2014 3:18 AM EDT Updated: Oct 31, 2014 12:30 PM EDT
http://www.wtrf.com/story/27055643/crews-responding-to-pipeline-explosion-on-mellotts-ridge-monroe-county

properties.Name: Monroe County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
On the morning of June 28, 2014, a fire broke out at a Halliburton fracking site. Flames engulfed the area, trucks began exploding, and thousands of gallons of toxic chemicals spilled into a tributary of the Ohio River, which supplies drinking water for millions of residents. More than 70,000 fish died, and it took five days for the EPA and its Ohio counterpart to get a full list of the chemicals polluting the waterway.

Source: "Halliburton fracking spill mystery: what chemicals polluted an Ohio waterway"". Mariah Blake. Grist. July 24, 2014.
http://grist.org/climate-energy/halliburton-fracking-spill-mystery-what-chemicals-polluted-an-ohio-waterway/

properties.Name: Morgan County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In May of 2014, 100 barrels of drilling lubrication fluid leaked from a fracking well into a nearby stream. Several residents were evacuated out of fear that natural gas, also leaking from the well, would cause an explosion. No one was injured and the spill was contained several days after it was discovered. However, environmental experts state that the oily lubricant could be harmful to marine life.

Source: “Oil Well Spills Into Southeast Ohio Creek” http://wosu.org/2012/news/2014/05/08/oil-well-spills-into-southeast-ohio-creek/. The Associated Press. WOSU Public Media. May 8, 2014.
http://wosu.org/2012/news/2014/05/08/oil-well-spills-into-southeast-ohio-creek/

properties.Name: Morrow County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
Mount Gilead nurse Donna Carver lives near more than a dozen injection wells. Emissions from fracking waste are often stored underground in injection wells. She has experienced burning eyes and nose, itchy skin, difficulty breathing, nausea, vomiting and headaches since the wells were drilled.

Source: "Coughing, Headaches, Fatigue: Is Fracking to Blame?" Public News Service -- OH. December 3, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.publicnewsservice.org/index.php?/content/article/29549-1

properties.Name: Noble County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
A worker was killed in an explosion at a fracking site in November of 2014. Norman Butler, 48 was working on a pump that moved toxic fracking fluid from the well into pipelines that transport the fluid to a processing facility. The cause of the explosion is unknown.

Source: “Worker killed in explosion at Noble County oil and gas facility”
http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/11/13/Worker-killed-at-Noble-County-oil-and-gas-well.html. Laura Arenschield. The Columbus Dispatch. November 14, 2014
http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2014/11/13/Worker-killed-at-Noble-County-oil-and-gas-well.html

properties.Name: Portage County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
Beckie Dean blames "enormous" damage to her house on a drilling operation across the street, about 1,000 feet away. She has documented cracks in her walls and ceiling, as well as constant noise that prevents her from sleeping.

Source: "Portage County: Drilling blamed for home damage". WKYC. December 5, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.wkyc.com/story/local/2012/12/05/3234595/

Debby and Jason Kline can light the liquid from their faucet on fire due to high levels of natural gas in the water. They live on Silica Sand Road in northeastern Portage County, near a sea of oil and gas wells. Within a mile of their home, two wells have been abandoned and another has recently been hydraulically fractured, or fracked, to stimulate natural gas production.

Source: "Portage County residents test water amid concerns of oil field contamination". Doug Livingston. Akron Beacon Journal. January 7, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.ohio.com/news/local-news/portage-county-residents-test-water-amid-concerns-of-oil-field-contamination-1.363107

properties.Name: Quaker City, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2014, a worker experienced burns on 30-50% of his body, with third-degree burns on his face and hands after a fracking well exploded while he was servicing it. The worker was airlifted to the hospital, but little information is available about his condition.

Source: “Man Burned In Guernsey County Fracking Site Explosion.” http://columbus.suntimes.com/cbus-news/7/98/12248/man-burned-in-guernsey-county-fracking-site-explosion/ WBNS-10TV. October 25 2014

properties.Name: Trumbull County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2015, an oil and gas facility owned by Kleese Development Associates leaked 2,000 gallons of waste into a tributary of Little Yankee Run. Fish, turtles, muskrats and other wildlife were killed by waste that accumulated in a pond and wetland, and residents in the township relied on bottled water for a week as officials investigated the spill. The Ohio Department of Natural Resources ordered KDA operations to close all five of its injection wells after the incident.

Source: "ODNR Shuts down 5 injection wells in Vienna, OH after spill". Marcellus Drilling News, April 8, 2015. Web. Accessed July 2, 2015. "Vienna oil spill leaves slew of dead animals". Amanda Smith. WKBN news. April 3, 2015. Web. Accessed July 2, 2015.
http://marcellusdrilling.com/2015/04/odnr-shuts-down-5-injection-wells-in-vienna-oh-after-spill/, http://wkbn.com/2015/04/03/cleanup-underway-at-vienna-spill/

properties.Name: Tyler County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
On April 11, 2013, workers were cleaning and inspecting a natural gas pumping facility in Tyler County when the facility exploded. 43-year-old Raymond Miller of Jeannette, and 56-year-old Bruce Phipps of Marietta, Ohio, lost their lives, and two other workers were injured in the blast.

Source: "UPDATE: Second Worker Dies from Injuries Suffered in Tyler County Gas Explosion". Associated Press. The News Center. April 16, 2013.
http://www.thenewscenter.tv/home/headlines/4-injured-in-gas-compressor-station-blast-202705891.html

In April 2013, an explosion at a Eureka Hunter pipeline operation killed Raymond Miller, 43, and Bruce Phipps, 56. The accident occurred at a compressor station. Two others were injured.

Source: "UPDATE: Second worker dies from injuries suffered in tyler county gas explosion". WTRF. WBOY.com. April 17, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.wboy.com/story/21949055/firefighters-working-to-subdue-gas-well-explosion-in-tyler-county-eureka-triad-hunter-magnum-hunter-resources-pipeline

In January 2014, a worker was injured in an explosion at a well pad owned by Jay Bee Oil & Gas. Drilling was completed on the pad a few months prior, and fracking started in December. The force of the explosion blew out the bottom of a large storage tank, and then blew the tank more than 100 feet over the top of some large frack trucks and into the hillside next to the road. The contents of the tanks, which apparently were fracking fluids, were leaked over the well pad and into the adjacent creek bottom.

Source: "Explosion at Tyler County Well Pad of Jay Bee Oil & Gas". Duane Nichols. FrackCheck. January 4, 2014. Web. Accessed July 15, 2015.
http://www.frackcheckwv.net/2014/01/04/explosion-at-tyler-county-well-pad-of-jay-bee-oil-gas/

properties.Name: Chippewa Township, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In March, 2013, a tank exploded at a well in Wayne County, Ohio, sending flames above the surrounding 30-ft. trees. Two tanks, less than 500 feet away from each other, were being constructed on the site; the second tank was damaged in the explosion.

Source: “Well Explodes in Eastern Wayne County.” Marilyn Miller. Akron Beacon Journal. March 15, 2013.
http://www.ohio.com/news/break-news/well-explodes-in-eastern-wayne-county-1.381615

properties.Name: Washington County, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, a tanker truck carrying brine for use in fracking flipped over an embankment, rolling down a hill and crashing into a home. The driver was seriously injured, and the owners of the home, who were sleeping at the time of the accident, were uninjured. Brine leaked from the truck and went underneath the home.

Source: "UPDATE: Fracking truck driver cited; brine not found in ditches and streams". Abbie Shrader. The News Center, WTAP. September 2, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.thenewscenter.tv/home/headlines/Authorities-Responding-to-Fracking-Truck-Accident-in-Washington-County-273456431.html

properties.Name: Youngstown, OH
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2013, the owner of an oil and gas drilling company was charged with violating the Clean Water Act after his company illegally dumped 20,000 gallons of fracking waste into a tributary of the Mahoning River. Steps were taken to revoke all operating permits granted to Hardrock Excavating owner, owned by Ben Lupo, which at one point was drilling at six fracking sites. The company was also fined for damage.

Source: “Reported waste dumping results in federal charges against fracking company owner.” James McCarty. Cleveland News. February 14, 2013.
http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/02/reported_fracking_waste_violat.html

properties.Name: Elk City, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
Randy Baumann and Christ Albert were killed in a Cactus drilling rig accident in 2012. Workers were using a 275-ton hydraulic crane to erect the mast of a drilling rig when a six-foot beam fell to the ground.

Source: "The human toll of a drilling boom in Oklahoma". Joe Wertz. State Impact. August 2, 2012. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
https://stateimpact.npr.org/oklahoma/2012/08/02/the-human-toll-of-a-drilling-boom-in-oklahoma/

properties.Name: Garvin County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2014, four workers were injured in a fire while they were performing maintenance on a natural gas pipeline operated by DCP Midstream. The workers were taken to a hospital in Lindsay.

Source: "Four are injured in pipeline fire near Lindsay". Jay F. Marks. NewsOK. August 21 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://newsok.com/four-are-injured-in-pipeline-fire-near-lindsay/article/5334363

properties.Name: Harper County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2013, a pipeline explosion forced residents within two miles to evacuate. Highways were shut down, and observers say the flames could be seen from 50 miles away. The pipeline was operated by Northern Natural Gas, a company that operates nearly 15,000 miles of natural gas pipelines in the United States.

Source: "Pipeline explosion in Oklahoma ignites natural gas, flames seen 50 miles away". Inquisitr. October 9, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.inquisitr.com/985603/pipeline-explosion-oklahoma-natural-gas-flames-video/

properties.Name: Kingfisher County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2014, 480 barrels of fracking-related hydrochloric acid -- nearly enough to fill an Olympic-sized swimming pool -- emptied out of a tank where it was stored. The acid was for use in a Blake Production well, and there were concerns that the acid could taint the water supply of Hennessey, a nearby town. The spill occurred in the Hawk's family's alfalfa field, a property on which they planned to build a home. The spill will not only effect the Hawk's immediate use and enjoyment, but future development may be impossible.

Source: "Frackers spill olympic pool's worth of hydrochloric acid in Oklahoma". Ari Phillips. ClimateProgress. July 31, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/07/31/3466283/olympic-pool-sized-hydrochloric-acid-spill-oklahoma/

properties.Name: Le Flore, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2013, residents complained that their water had been contaminated by a produced water disposal pit. The pit into which waste-water was dumped was not lined. At least 14 residents in the neighborhood of the 20 homes closest to the dump site now have cancer.

Source: "Oklahomans Claim Fracking Waste Polluted their water". NewsOn6. Oklahoma's Own. November 11, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.newson6.com/story/23938227/fracking-wastewater-dumped-in-small-oklahoma-town

properties.Name: Noble County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
Norman Butler, 48, was killed in an oil well drilling accident involving a condensate pumping skid in November 2014. The accident occurred as pump upgrades were being performed by Blue Racer Midstream, CONSOL's midstream service provider in Noble County.

Source: "UPDATE: Victim ID'd in Fatal Oil Well Drilling Accident in Noble County". Colin Lawler. November 16, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.wtrf.com/story/27372541/crews-respond-to-fatal-oil-well-drilling-accident-in-noble-county

properties.Name: Rogers County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
Max and Casey Murphey and their three young children discovered an uncapped gas well under their home. They have footage of gas seeping up from their yard that is not only causing bubbles on their driveway and sidewalk but is also flammable. Their three children, who were all born healthy, are now experiencing health problems, especially difficulty breathing.

Source: "Owasso couple: 'Strange gas turning dream home into nightmare'". FOX news. May 30, 2014. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://m.fox23.com/news/news/breaking-news/owasso-couple-strange-gas-turning-dream-home-into-/ngHMD/

properties.Name: Oklahoma County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2015, a leak from an oil and gas facility owned by Gastar leaked a saltwater mix onto the property of local homeowners. Homeowner David Loftis was concerned for his livestock, after the wastewater spill ran onto his pasture and pond, killing vegetation and fish.

Source: "Pollution spill kills pond fish, upsets landowner beyond words". Andrew Donley. NewsChannel4. Web. Accessed July 1, 2015.
http://kfor.com/2015/04/30/land-owner-so-upset-over-pond-pollution-he-cant-find-his-words/

properties.Name: Texas County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2014, a DCP straight compressor station caught fire and exploded 13 miles northeast of Guymon, putting two workers in critical condition from burns. Straight Elementary School, nearby, was evacuated.

Source: "Two workers critically injured in explosion near Guymon". News9. November 21, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.news9.com/story/27449668/two-workers-critically-injured-in-explosion-near-guymon

properties.Name: Buffalo Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Russel Evans, a West Virginia truck driver, was splashed with flowback water at a Buffalo Township well site in May 2013. Evans backed his truck up to a "sloppy pond" used to store reused frack water and noticed that water was leaking from the back hatch of his tanker truck. He claims that he was doused with water when he attempted to stop the leak, and was told by a Range Resources employee that the water was harmless. As a result he stayed in his wet clothes for four hours, and suffered from chemical burns, blisters, and rashes.

Source: "Truck driver sues Range Resources over injury claims". Emily Petsko. Observer-Reporter. May 8, 2015. Web. Accessed July 1, 2015.
http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20150508/NEWS01/150509493

properties.Name: Milan, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, a worker at Blankenship Service Company was burned in a blast at a natural gas related business in Bradford County. The accident occurred when he was cutting open a tank along Route 220 in Milan, north of Towanda.

Source: "Worker burned in 'blast' in Bradford County". Bill Michlowski. WNEP. September 9, 2014. Web. Accessed July 10, 2015.
http://wnep.com/2014/09/09/worker-burned-in-blast-in-bradford-county/

properties.Name: Connoquenessing Township
properties.PopupInfo:
Residents of the Woodlands, a poor, rural community in Connoquenessing Township, have experienced problems with water contamination after Rex Energy constructed 15 drilling pads and 65 horizontal wells within a few miles of the residents' homes. The Higgins family uses replacement water, and Russ and Connie Kelley had pet rabbits that refused to drink the contaminated water and died of thirst.

Source: "A day in the life of a water bank". Natasha Khan. PublicSource. May 13, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://publicsource.org/investigations/day-life-of-water-bank#.VZ2Z8vm-1cb

properties.Name: Carmichaels, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Pam Judy and her family live 780 feet away from a compressor station. They have experienced headaches, fatigue, dizziness, nausea and nosebleeds. Blood tests have shown exposure to benzene and other chemicals used in fracking. Air tests found 16 chemicals in Judy's yard, including benzene. The family's yard is fume ridden -- Pam has reported smells like diesel, kerosene and chlorine.

Source: "As air pollution from fracking rises, EPA to set rules". Renee Schoof. McClatchy Newspapers. April 16, 2012.
http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/04/16/145383/as-air-pollution-from-fracking.html

properties.Name: Centre County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Donal Ludwig, who lives near an NCL gas well, found that his water had been contaminated with high levels of barium, manganese, iron, arsenic and lead. He showers at a nearby campground and hauls his own clean drinking water. When Ludwig tried to shower at his home, he experience headaches and extreme ringing in his ears. When he used the dishwasher, his eyes watered uncontrollably and swelled shut.

Source: "Did gas drilling contaminate his water? Centre County man is frustrated at his government's response: Anaysis by Matt Zencey". Matt Zency. The Patriot News. November 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.pennlive.com/opinion/2014/11/gas_drilling_suspected_water_c.html

properties.Name: Fayette County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Jerry Yeager and his wife live a few hundred feet from a compressor station, next to a fracking site down the hill. They report "horrific" smells, and both have frequent bouts of nausea, as well as vision, respiratory and neurological problems. One of their grandchildren woke up screaming that he couldn't breathe when he visited during the holidays.

Source: "Fracking in Pennslyvania sets up dilemma for locals: Quick money or long-term health concerns?" Lynne Peeples. Huffington Post. January 25, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/25/fracking-pennsylvania-natural-gas-lease-landman_n_2546824.html?utm_hp_ref=mostpopular

Six Pennsylvania families who claim nearby gas wells are a nuisance sued Chevron for compensation. Twelve wells near the residents’ properties have been leaking natural gas, methane and other toxic and radioactive substances into the air and ground, according to the complaint. Faulty design, construction and maintenance are allegedly to blame.

“Chevron among drillers facing suit over nuisance gas wells.” Sophia Pearson & Jim Efstathiou Jr. Bloomberg News. June 10, 2013.
http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-06-07/chevron-among-drillers-facing-suit-over-nuisance-gas-wells.html

properties.Name: Uniontown, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, seven massive train cars of an 80-car train carrying fracking sand derailed. Together they carried about 135,000 pounds of sand, some of which spilled along the tracks. One of the cars came to rest a few feet from the front porch of a house.

Source: "Train hauling fracking sand derailes in Uniontown, nearly hits house". Ross Guidotti. CBS Pittsburgh. January 22, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2015/01/22/train-hauling-sand-derails-in-uniontown/

properties.Name: Dunkard Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In Dunkard Township, one worker was injured and another went missing after a natural gas well exploded and caught fire in southwestern Pennsylvania, near the West Virginia border. The incident occurred in February 2014.

Source: "1 Injured, 1 Unaccounted for at Greene Co. Gas Well Fire". Ross Guidotti. CBS Pittsburgh. February 11, 2014.
http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2014/02/11/crews-respond-to-greene-county-gas-well-fire/

properties.Name: Greene County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
