In July 2014, the driver of a water tank truck owned by E.C.M. Energy Company was killed and another person was injured in a rollover accident. The truck was headed south when the driver lost control on a right-hand curve in the road.

Source: "1 killed, 1 injured in water tank truck rollover crash in Greene Co." CBS Pittsburgh. July 16, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2014/07/16/1-killed-1-injured-in-water-tank-truck-rollover-crash-in-greene-co/#.U8fGNGFfhpo.facebook

properties.Name: Lawrence Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2010, a natural gas well blowout spewed at least 35,000 gallons of wastewater into the air for 16 hours until the well was finally capped the following day. Pennsylvania's Department of Environmental Protection ordered the well completion firm C. C. Forbes to halt all post-fracking activities in the state pending investigation, and Texas-based EOG Resources Inc., the well's owner, received a similar suspension from drilling and fracking operations.

Source: Source: "Marcellus Shale well blowout prompts second DEP suspension". Anya Litvak. Pittsburgh Business Times. June 9, 2010.
http://www.bizjournals.com/pittsburgh/stories/2010/06/07/daily32.html?jst=b_ln_hl

properties.Name: Leroy Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
During the hydraulic fracturing process a Chesapeake Energy well suffered a blowout in April 2011, spilling thousands of gallons of fracking fluid into the surrounding area. While no one was hurt, seven families had to be evacuated, and the fluid leaked into nearby Towanda Creek.

Source: Source: "Gas Well Spews Polluted Water." The Associated Press. The New York Times, April 20, 2011.
http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/21/us/21frack.html?_r=4&scp=1&sq=bradford%20blowout%20"april%2020"%20gas%20chesapeak&st=cse&

In May 2012, residents of Leroy Township began noticing bubbles in their well water; soon after, several residents' faucet water turned “coal-black.” The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection blamed a hydraulic fracturing site owned by Chesapeake Energy that had been leaking methane gas into local groundwater.

Source: Source: “Methane Making an Appearance in PA Water Supplies.” Scott Detrow. NPR. Aug. 28, 2012.
http://www.npr.org/2012/08/28/160128351/methane-making-an-appearance-in-pa-water-supplies#.UDytx3ED_Qw.gmail

properties.Name: Mercer Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, about 35 residents living near a natural gas well site owned by Hillcorp Energy Company in Mercer county were forced to leave their homes after a piece of equipment caught fire. The equipment was housed in a metal building at the edge of the site, and is used to separate oil, gas, and water.

Source: "Gas well fire sparks evacuation". Nadine Grimley. WKBN 27. September 6, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://wkbn.com/2014/09/06/gas-well-fire-sparks-evacuation/

properties.Name: New Columbia, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
A truck carrying hydrochloric acid for drilling leaked near New Columbia, creating a toxic chemical cloud. At about 10:20 p.m in August 2012., Gregory Pellicer Jr., 28, of Lawton Oklahoma, noticed a cloud billowing behind the Halliburton Energy Services tanker he was driving east on Route 80. A quarter-sized hole was observed in the truck, and an estimated 250 gallons of hydrochloric acid leaked out.

Source: Source: "People flee as chemical cloud hovers near New Columbia". Marcia Moore and John Finnerty. The Daily Item. August 11, 2012.
http://www.dailyitem.com/news/people-flee-as-chemical-cloud-hovers-near-new-columbia/article_db47623b-63fc-5819-aeb3-e9ebae0d3892.html

properties.Name: Portage, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
After working as a trucker for brine, or fracking wastewater, from natural gas wells, Randy Moyer began to come down with crippling headaches, blurred vision, dizziness and a large red rash covering almost half of his body. He has been unable to work for 14 months as a result of his time trucking this wastewater.

Source: Source: “Fracking wastewater can be highly radioactive”. Rachel Morgan, Times Online. January 24, 2013.
http://www.timesonline.com/news/local_news/fracking-wastewater-can-be-highly-radioactive/article_ac1dd0e8-5a2f-57aa-8c5d-1d80273e261e.html

properties.Name: Kingsley, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Pauline Fallon's family owned a dairy farm in Kingsley for many generations. Shortly after drilling began in the area, a black sediment was found in their well water, which tests showed to be manganese oxide. Many neighbors experienced similar water contamination. People and animals at the farm began to get sick, and after the family found that bringing in outside water was not affordable, they were forced to sell their cows and shutter operations.

Source: "A visit with some folks in fracking land". Bill Chameides. The Green Grok, Duke Nicholas School of the Environment. June 22, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://blogs.nicholas.duke.edu/thegreengrok/a-trip-to-fracking-land-part-2/

properties.Name: Springville Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2014, a water-truck driver for the natural gas industry was crushed by his own vehicle and died after his truck slid on a snowy hill. David D. Nesbitt, 51, of Wilkes-Barre, was driving at low speed when the incident occurred. He had just taken fresh water to a job site and was hauling a load of waste water.

Source: "Water-truck driver killed in Susquehanna County". Brendan Gibbons. The Times Tribune. December 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2014.
http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/water-truck-driver-killed-in-susquehanna-county-1.1801475#.VIr0pm6UQ9U.facebook

properties.Name: Springville, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2008, several hundred gallons of diesel fuel leaked from a natural gas well site and flowed into a Springville wetland.

Source: "Prosperity in Pipeline." Laura Legere. The Scranton Times Tribune. September 28, 2008.

In March 2012, an explosion at a compressor station blew a hole in the roof of the complex holding the engines. The explosion shook homes as far as a half-mile away and drew emergency responders from multiple nearby counties. Damage was contained to the site but black smoke billowed for several hours and necessitated an emergency shutdown of the site. The station, which pressurizes and dehydrates natural gas from the Marcellus Shale wells in the county, moved 364 million cubic feet of gas per day before being shut down.

Source: “Explosion rocks natural gas compressor station.” Laura Legere. The Times-Tribune. March 30, 2012.

In January 2015, a water truck smashed into the back of two fracking trucks and an SUV, killing 27-year-old Andrew Stevens, the driver of the SUV. Stevens was a Marine, husband, and father of two children.

Source: "UPDATE: Marine killed during fiery wreck". Andrew Forgotch. Nextar Broadcasting Inc, PA homepage. January 2, 2015. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/explosion-rocks-natural-gas-compressor-station-1.1292502#axzz1qXoIB0X1

properties.Name: Susquehanna County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2012, an explosion at a natural gas compressor station in Susquehanna County blew a hole in the roof of the complex holding the engines, shaking homes as far as a half-mile away and drawing emergency responders from nearby counties. The Lathrop station pressurizes and dehydrates natural gas from Marcellus Shale; gas was leaked after the explosion before the valve was shut off.

Source: Source: “Explosion Rocks Natural Gas Compressor Station.” Laura Legere. The Times-Tribune. March 30, 2012.
http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/explosion-rocks-natural-gas-compressor-station-1.1292502#axzz1qXoIB0X1

properties.Name: Tunkhannock, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2013, at least two homes were damaged after over 9,000 gallons of flow-back fluid spilled from a site along Sickler Road outside Tunkhannock, Pennsylvania. The fluid that spilled flowed onto a miniature horse farm and into a farmhouse basement, along with a garage across the road. The spill was caused after a hose broke loose from a tank at a Carrizo Oil and Gas drilling site.

Source: “Spill on Wyoming County Road Affects Neighbors.” Dave Scarnato. 16 WNEP. April 30, 2013.
http://wnep.com/2013/04/30/spill-on-wyoming-county-road/

Audrey Gozdiskowski has lived in Tunkahannock Township for 35 years and says she has never known the haze to be worse than it has been in the three years since the arrival of unconventional gas extraction. She has experienced nausea, headaches, throat constriction, burning eyes and noise pollution.

Source: "Idling through the summer haze in Frackland". Tara M. Zrinski. Shale Reporter. June 30, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.shalereporter.com/blog/tara_zrinski/article_546c6d3c-006e-11e4-b7e8-0017a43b2370.html

properties.Name: Brokenstraw Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2014, 26-year old Nikolai Briggs was killed in an explosion while welding a crude oil tank in Brokenstraw Township. He was on top of the tank when the welding torch ignited vapor inside the tank, causing the blast. There were no witnesses, and Briggs' body was found 60 feet away from the tank.

Source: "NW Pa. man killed while welding crude oil tank". Associated Press. Pocono Record. March 13, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20140313/NEWS90/140319903/-1/news

properties.Name: Chartiers Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2013, a flare occurred at a MarkWest natural gas processing plant in Chartiers Township. Suzanne Bastien, who lives less than two miles from the plant, experienced symptoms such as burning eyes, throat, nausea and a metallic taste in her mouth. This was the third flaring incident at the plant in six weeks, causing the state Department of Environmental Protection to investigate.

Source: "Residents worried after latest MarkWest flare". Emily Petsko and Mike Jones. Observer Reporter. August 23, 2013. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.observer-reporter.com/article/20130823/NEWS01/130829753#.UhpXlT8qKx8

properties.Name: Houston, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2014, a gas pipeline owned by Williams Energy Company exploded and caught fire, causing the evacuation of 12 families on Christmas Eve. According to a spokesperson for Williams Energy Company, the pipeline originates in Marshall County, West Virginia, and transports ethane to the Houston, Pennsylvania area in Washington County.

Source: "Gas pipeline fire in Washington Co. prompts urgent evacuations". WPXI News. December 25, 2014. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://www.wpxi.com/news/news/local/gas-pipeline-fire-washington-co-prompts-urgent-eva/njZ3q/

Gary Andreis' house in Cartiers-Houston is downhill from a natural gas compressor station that he says has flooded his yard and poisoned his well, forcing him and his family to live on bottled water. The family is filing a suit against MarkWest, the owner of the compressor station.

Source: "KD Investigates: As Drilling Ramps up, so do the Lawsuits". Andy Sheehan. CBS Pittsburgh. March 10, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2015/03/10/kd-investigates-as-drilling-ramps-up-so-do-the-lawsuits/

properties.Name: Wellsboro, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Denise and Jerry Gee, along with their son Jeremiah, live next door to land that has been leased to Shell Appalachia for drilling. In 2010, a gas drilling site appeared about 100 yards from a pond on their property, and mere days later their well-water began appearing murky and contaminated. Though the family sought aid from Shell to repair the damages to their property, they have not received any assistance.

Source: Source: “Tioga County family struggles with methane in its well water.” Cheryl Clark. The Sun-Gazette. July 2, 2011.

http://www.sungazette.com/page/content.detail/id/565860/Tioga-County-family-struggles-with-methane-in-its-well-water.html?nav=5011

properties.Name: Westmoreland County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
Starting in 2012, Ralph Brown, the Latins family, and Ken and Mildred Geary have experienced reduced property values and water with a foul chemical odor as a result of WPX Appalachia LLC's leaky wastewater impoundment. Their wells have been contaminated by fracking waste.

Source: "Families' well water disrupted near Ligonier". Don Hopey. Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. July 4, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.post-gazette.com/local/westmoreland/2014/07/05/Families-well-water-disrupted-near-Ligonier/stories/201407050100

In January 2015, an explosion and fire occurred at a Consol Energy natural gas well, causing a worker to be severely burned on his face and arms. He was flown by emergency helicopter to a burn unit.

Source: "Consol contractor airlifted after being burned in Derry fire". Joe Napsha. Triblive. February 15, 2015. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://triblive.com/mobile/7785224-96/fire-department-spokesman

properties.Name: Wyoming County, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2013, 9,000 gallons of fracking fluid spilled from a well site owned by Carrizzo Oil and Gas. According to the Department of Environmental Protection, a faulty hose came loose at the site.

Source: "Fracking Fluid Cleanup Continues". Amanda Kelley. WNEP. May 1, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://wnep.com/2013/05/01/fracking-fluid-cleanup-continues/

A Wyoming County oil well, operated by the Texas-based Carrizo Oil and Gas, spewed more than a quarter million gallons of highly pressurized fracking wastewater, causing evacuations of nearby homes and buildings in March 2013. Methane gas leaked out of the well, prompting EPA to test the water and air quality in the area.

Source: Source: “After Fracking Wastewater Spill, Residents and Regulators Believe Water is Safe.” Marie Cusick. NPR. March 19, 2013.
http://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2013/03/19/after-fracking-wastewater-spill-residents-and-regulators-believe-water-is-safe/

properties.Name: Youngstown, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2013 the owner of Hardrock LLC was charged with violating the Clean Water Act and faces up to three years in jail and a 250,000 dollar fine. Over the past year he allegedly ordered his employees to dump more than 20,000 of fracking waste into sewers that empty into the Mahoning River watershed.

Source: Source: “Reported waste dumping results in federal charges against fracking company owner”. James F. McCarty. The Plain Dealer. February 14, 2013.
http://www.cleveland.com/metro/index.ssf/2013/02/reported_fracking_waste_violat.html

properties.Name: Aledo, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2008, Joyce Burton, a worker for L&B Transport, was unloading hydrochloric acid at Frac Tech's Aledo facility, when a hose fitting came loose and sprayed the acid onto her face and body. According to Burton, the two safety showers in the facility were either not working properly or were locked and not accessible. She suffered serious chemical burns to her face, chest and abdomen.

Source: Frac Tech to pay $450K settlement to woman burned by acid". Jaime Adame. Abilene Reporter-News. November 16, 2011. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.reporternews.com/business/woman-alleging-no-working-safety-showers-at-frac

properties.Name: Arlington, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2015, a well owned by Vantage Energy leaked thousands of gallons of frackwater into Rush Creek and Village Creek, resulting in the evacuation of nearby homes. Vantage waited more than two hours before calling 911, and may be facing charges.

Source: "Driller may face fines in Arlington gas well emergency". Susan Schrock. Star-Telegram. April 14, 2015. Web. Accessed July 1, 2015.
http://www.star-telegram.com/news/local/community/arlington/article18540473.html

properties.Name: Barstow, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2013, a well blowout near Barstow caused the death of two men. Juan Rios was pronounced dead at the scene and Olegario Rios was airlifted to the hospital where he later died. Two other men, Roman Galindo and Jose Cruz, were airlifted to the University Medical Center in Lubbock. Officials on the scene determined that a pulling unit belonging to Basic Energy Services was in the process of rigging up on the well when it blew out.

Source: Source: "Two Killed, Two Injured After Well Blowout Near Barstow". Staff Report. NewsWest 9. April 5, 2013.
http://www.newschannel10.com/story/21893579/one-killed-three-injured-after-oil-rig-blowout-north-of-barstow

properties.Name: Barnhart, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
The fracking boom in Barnhart, Texas caused a huge demand for fracking water. The town's wells appear to have run dry because of water being extracted for fracking use. Residents report that water troubles began when fracking began in the area. Farmers have lost livestock and crops, and the town was water-rationed.

Source: "A Texan tragedy: ample oil, no water". Suzanne Goldenberg. The Gaurdian. August 11, 2013. Web. Accessed July 1, 2015.
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/aug/11/texas-tragedy-ample-oil-no-water

properties.Name: Borden County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Joel and Betty Dennis live near a Westex Systems disposal waste pit, and have complained of nausea and odors so bad that they had to stay indoors. The smells they reported were characteristic of potentially lethal hydrogen sulfide. Despite the family's complaints, another pit holding 163 barrels of oil and gas waste was approved.

Source: "In Fracking's Wake: Open pits offer cheap disposal for oil and gas sludge, but health worries mount". David Hasemyer and Zahra Hirji. InsideClimateNews. October 2, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://books.insideclimatenews.org/infrackingswake

properties.Name: Brazos County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Monica and Richard Palasota are concerned about ongoing fracking at a well owned by Halcon that's 1,800 feet away from their house. They have experienced vibrations that rattle the windows against their frames, a coating of dust on their family truck, and they have been unable to sleep due to 40 days of noise from the well. John Opersteny and family have experienced headaches and worsening of asthma, as well as lack of sleep from the noise.

Source: "Residents concerned about health, pollution from fracking near their homes". Emily Wilkins. The Eagle. April 26, 2015. Web. Accessed July 2, 2015.
http://www.theeagle.com/news/local/residents-concerned-about-health-pollution-from-fracking-near-their-homes/article_ec5607f9-aed3-5153-9826-6d2dc835c010.html

properties.Name: Burleson County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2014, a natural gas leak at a Comstock oil and gas well caused the evacuation of 28 families in a two-mile radius. The cause of the leak appeared to be a faulty valve, and according to the county's emergency coordinator, a "significant amount" of natural gas and a small quantity of water escaped the well.

Source: "Families back home after Burleson County gas leak evacuation". Eagle Staff Report. The Eagle. December 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://www.theeagle.com/news/local/families-back-home-after-burleson-county-gas-leak-evacuation/article_0ca2e9e5-e290-5553-8a79-540e639af235.html

properties.Name: Corpus Christi, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2013, a 25-year-old father of two with a new baby on the way was killed at a Coastal Drilling company drill site after a metal structure fell over, crushing him under tons of heavy metal. This is one of many accidents to occur in 2009 on the Eagle Ford Shale site.

Source: “Eagle Ford pay is high but work can be fatal.” John Tedesco. My San Antonio. Feb. 26, 2013.
http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/energy/article/Eagle-Ford-pay-is-high-but-work-can-be-fatal-4285405.php

properties.Name: Culberson County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2013, a 22-year-old Carlsbad man was killed in an oil rig accident. He was working on a drilling rig for Patriot Drilling when a 24-foot section of pipe fell on him. He was pronounced dead at the scene.

Source: "Carlsbad man dies in oil rig accident in Culberson County, Texas". Stella Davis. Carlsbad Current-Argus. March 21, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.currentargus.com/ci_22835540/carlsbad-man-dies-oil-rig-accident-culberson-county

properties.Name: Denton, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2013, a gas pipe separated from a well owned by Eagle Ridge Operating LLC, causing fracking water and small traces of natural gas to leak from the pipe. A Denton hazardous materials unit was at the site for nearly five hours, and the authorities evacuated four homes as a precaution.

Source: Source: "Denton responders work gas well pipe emergency". Megan Gray. Denton Record-Chronicle. April 19, 2013.
http://www.dentonrc.com/local-news/local-news-headlines/20130419-gas-pipe-leak-capped.ece

properties.Name: Denton County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Fracking is prevalent in this area, and residents have been reporting many health problems in correlation with drilling activity. Rebecca Williams lives near a compressor station and heavy gas-well development, and has experienced rashes, sharp headaches and repeated bouts of pneumonia respiratory problems, nosebleeds, and vomiting. Her dog also has rashes. Justin Eaklor has four Barnett shale wells just under two-thirds of a mile from his house, and has been diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Taylor Ishee lives within a mile and a half of 37 active gas wells, and has been diagnosed with Burkitt leukemia, a rare type of cancer.

Source: "Big Oil, Bad Air: Health worries pervade North Texas fracking zone". Jamie Smith Hopkins. December 11, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.publicintegrity.org/2014/12/11/16396/health-worries-pervade-north-texas-fracking-zone?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+publici_rss+(The+Center+for+Public+Integrity+Latest+Stories)

In January 2013, a 63-year-old man was found dead near a natural gas pad in Denton County. The man was unloading condensate, a natural gas liquid, from the tank of his truck into a holding tank when something went wrong; he was found near a spillover of condensate, the likely cause of death. He was working for a subsidiary of ConocoPhillips.

Source: “Man found dead near natural gas pad site.” Megan Gray. Denton Record-Chronicle. Jan. 17, 2013.
http://www.dentonrc.com/local-news/local-news-headlines/20130117-man-found-dead-near-natural-gas-pad-site.ece

Veronica Kronvall bought a home in north Texas in 2007. Four years later, an energy company drilled five wells behind her home, the closest two within 300 ft. of her garden. After the drilling began, Kronvall, 52, starting having nosebleeds, nausea and headaches. Her home lost nearly a quarter of its value and some of her neighbors went into foreclosure.

Source: "Fracking hell: what it's really like to live next to a shale gas well". Suzanne Goldenberg. The Guardian. December 14, 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/dec/14/fracking-hell-live-next-shale-gas-well-texas-us

properties.Name: Dimmit County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, five men died when their van slammed into a tanker truck carrying shale crude oil. The vehicle burst into flames, and three others were injured. The accident happened in the heart of the fracking field southwest of San Antonio, an area where traffic accidents have become much more frequent since the fracking boom.

Source: "Five dead in crash in South Texas oil field". Jim Forsyth. Reuters. January 15, 2015. Web. Accessed July 7, 2015.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/15/us-usa-crash-texas-oil-idUSKBN0KO2J020150115

properties.Name: Floresville, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Fred and Amber Lyssy raise pigs, goats and cattle on a 564-acre organic farm in Wilson County outside Floresville. Their land is surrounded by wells, flares and holding tanks. Six of their dogs suffered mysterious deaths -- five died within a few days of each other in February 2013. When inspectors visited the area, they detected hydrogen sulfide and other unspecified emissions coming from a Hunt Oil complex with 12 crude oil tanks and a flare.

Source: "Fracking the Eagle Ford Shale". Jim Morris, Lisa Song and David Hasemyer. The Weather Channel: The Center for Public Integrity. February 18, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://stories.weather.com/fracking

properties.Name: Fort Worth, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2014, a fracking wastewater truck fatally struck a teenage bicycle rider. Deston Bibbs, 14, died at John Peter Smith Hospital in Fort Worth. Based on a video taken by a red-light camera at the intersection, detectives determined that the truck was an 18-wheeler belonging to frack waste hauler 3-Star Daylighting.

Source: "A fracking truck driver who ran over a 14-year-old boy in Fort Worth has been cleared of wrongdoing". Eric Nicholson. Dallas Observer. August 6, 2013. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.dallasobserver.com/news/a-fracking-truck-driver-who-ran-over-a-14-year-old-boy-in-fort-worth-has-been-cleared-of-wrongdoing-7149673

properties.Name: Gillett, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2013, a tank farm explosion left a 38-year-old worker with serious burns. There were a total of nine tanks on fire and two open tanks, containing wastewater from fracking operations going on in the area. This wastewater could contain oil and other chemicals. The tanks were owned by Gulf Coast Acquisitions.

Source: "Cause of tank farm explosion that injured 1 under investigation". ABC KSAT. October 8, 2013. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.ksat.com/content/pns/ksat/news/2013/10/08/cause-of-tank-farm-explosion-that-injured-1-under-investigation.html

properties.Name: Harris County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2014, Vilma Marenco was hit by a flatbed truck carrying a load of steel pipes for use in drilling. The 18-wheeler ran a red light and crushed her Chevy Cavalier. According to the Texas Department of Public Safety, the company involved, R & F Quality Transportation, shouldn't have had a truck on the road at all because it had amassed a number of safety violations ranging from defective brakes to a driver smoking marijuana behind the wheel.

Source: "In Texas, Traffic Deaths Climb Amid Fracking Boom". Andrew Schneider. NPR. October 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://www.npr.org/2014/10/02/352980756/in-texas-traffic-deaths-climb-amid-fracking-boom

properties.Name: Houston County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2014, a worker was injured when a pressure valve blew open on a liquid gas well, spraying him with an undetermined liquid gas that resulted in chemical burns. He was transported by helicopter to East Texas Medical Center.

Source: "UPDATE: Man injured at gas well has suffered chemicals burns". Tyler Morning Telegraph. October 23, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2014.
http://www.tylerpaper.com/article/view/article_id/207330/headline/update-man-injured-at-gas-well-has-suffered-chemical-burns/section/TP-News+Local#.VFPpXVfiG2U

properties.Name: Karnes County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Cynthia Dupnik started feeling sick shortly after Marathon Oil started drilling near home. Marathon sent a team to take air samples on her property, but they never returned with the test results. On the evening of December 13, 2013, noise from a nearby tank battery site was louder than usual and the air smelled like rotten eggs. Dupnik experienced a metallic taste in her mouth and had a hard time breathing. Before drilling started, her family had no health issues, but now they suffer from fatigue, headaches, rashes, eyestrain, sore throats, dizziness, nosebleeds and respiratory problems.

Source: "Eagle Ford Shale: Breathe at your own risk". Julie Dermansky. Desmog Blog. December 30, 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
http://www.desmogblog.com/2013/12/30/eagle-ford-shale-breathe-your-own-risk

properties.Name: La Porte, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2013, a fire at a pipeline facility owned by Enterprise Products Partners burned for four hours, causing two injuries before it was extinguished. Natural gas liquids were ignited in the fire, but it is unclear how it began. The facility loads natural gas liquids and crude oil into barges at rates of up to 5,000 barrels per hour. The barges move oil and natural gas between U.S. ports.

Source: "2 injured at La Porte pipeline facility where fire burned for four hours". Dale Lezon and Zain Shauk. Chron. December 31, 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/2-injured-at-La-Porte-pipeline-facility-where-5104540.php?cmpid=htx

properties.Name: La Salle County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Charles Covert's ranch is right next to a production facility that includes tanks for the storage of crude oil, a tank for produced water, and a flare that wafts black smoke toward his property. According to doctors, Covert suffered ill health effects of hydrogen sulfide, a flammable gas with a rotten-egg smell that is often created in wells along with oil and gas. He has a loss of lung function and uses numerous medications, including inhalers and nasal sprays. The Texas Commission on Environmental Air Quality found that the operator of the production facility failed to prevent air emissions. State investigators had irritated eyes upon visits to the ranch, and smelled the odor of sour gas.

Source: "Something's in the air". Jennifer Hiller. San Antonio Express News. July 20, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.expressnews.com/news/energy/article/Something-s-in-the-air-4676882.php?t=f8cfae68c3dffd779b

properties.Name: Lavaca County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2013, a Nabors oil rig operated by Enron Oil and Gas exploded after oil rig workers were drilling horizontally into the Eagle Ford Shale. Those living near the well site were evacuated from their homes.

Source: "Residents, workers evacuate from site of oil rig explosion". Bianca Montes. Victoria Advocate. August 29, 2015. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2013/aug/29/oil_rig_fire_folo_bm_083013_218438/

properties.Name: Orla, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2014, two people died and nine were injured in an explosion at a production facility near Orla. The explosion took place when pressure built up as workers were changing a wellhead at the production facility. The area in which the explosion took place is owned by RKI exploration & Production.

Source: "Two dead, nine injured in Loving County explosion". Audris Ponce. OA Online. April 30, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.oaoa.com/news/crime_justice/law_enforcement/article_c911d548-d092-11e3-82c7-001a4bcf6878.html

properties.Name: Navarro County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2013, a casing ruptured in a gas well just outside Corsicana, causing one injury. About four gallons per minute of injection fluid and drilling mud were leaking from the well.

Source: "1 injured when casing ruptures at Corsicana gas well". WFAA staff. WFAA. July 25, 2013. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.wfaa.com/story/local/2015/07/21/14073798/

properties.Name: Newton, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2013, a 10-inch wide underground gas pipe operated by DCP Midstream ruptured, spewing natural gas into the air. Emergency responders evacuated about a dozen people from their homes in the area. According to a DCP spokeswoman, the pipeline was a gathering line, meaning it carries mined gas to processing facilities.

Source: "Gas line not yet repaired after explosion in Buna". Tim Monzingo. Beaumont Enterprise. September 24, 2013. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.beaumontenterprise.com/news/article/Gas-line-not-yet-repaired-after-explosion-in-Buna-4838918.php

properties.Name: Panola County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2011, Mike Allen crashed into a heavy truck owned by Water Resources. The truck was hauling water to a fracking site, and it was stopped on the road without turn signals or flashing lights.

Source: "Parker County truck wreck lawsuit one of two settled for combined $11.7 million". Weatherford Democrat. June 28, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.weatherforddemocrat.com/news/local_news/parker-county-truck-wreck-lawsuit-one-of-two-settled-for/article_c48e4897-fd53-57a5-ad47-25145d209569.html

properties.Name: Pappy Elkins Lake, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
XTO Energy pumped nearly 1.4 million gallons of water out of Pappy Elkins Lake in 2011 to use in fracking operations. In August 2014, water levels were extremely low, and a massive fish kill occurred, with thousands of carp floating on the surface of the lake.

Source: "Massive fish kil at Dalworthington Gardens lake". Todd Unger. WFAA 8 ABC. August 26, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/local/tarrant-county/2014/08/26/fish-kill-pappy-elkins-lake-dalworthington-gardens/14662529/

properties.Name: Parker County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2010, the EPA discovered two contaminated water wells in southern Parker county. Federal regulators feared some homes could actually explode if people kept using the water. An emergency order was subsequently issued to test all the wells in the area near the Aqua Texas plant. Residents in and around the plant experienced murky drinking and bath water after the wells were contaminated.

Source: “Map pinpoints contaminated water in Parker County.” Chris Hawes. WFAA 8. Dec. 8 2010. “Just Below the Surface.” Pennie Boyett. Denton Record-Chronicle. March 29, 2011.
http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/Map-pinpoints-contaminated-water-in-Parker-County--111564849.html, http://www.dentonrc.com/local-news/special-projects/gas-well-drilling-headlines/20110329-just-below-the-surface.ece

In June 2014, homeowners Marcus and Laura Marsden of Aledo won a lawsuit against Titan Operating, which built gas well near the couple's home. Titan drilled less than 300 feet from the Marsden's home, caused flooding of their property, did not use promised sound mufflers, and did not restore or properly fence the drill site.

Source: "Parker County couple wins nuisance lawsuit against Titan Operating". Shlachter, Baker & Fuquay. Star-Telegram. June 29, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.star-telegram.com/news/business/biz-columns-blogs/baker-ahles-kaskovich/article3863533.html

David and Merideth Hull experienced 30 earthquakes between November 2013 and May 2014. They are one of dozens of families who have been hit by a rash of earthquakes since November, and they point to oil and gas disposal wells as likely culprits. The wells dispose of wastewater used in hydraulic fracturing for natural gas in the nearby Barnett Shale.

Source: "Fracking wells possible culprit of Texas earthquakes". Rick Jervis. USA Today. June 1, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/06/01/earthquakes-texas-fracking-wells/9765659/

properties.Name: Perrin, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
On August 2, 2014, a water well exploded in Perrin, TX, burning a family of four, including a 4-year-old child. The well was contaminated with  methane gas from nearby natural gas fracking operations. The family is now involved in a lawsuit with the energy companies who own the gas wells, which are located approximately 1,000 feet away from the family's water well. 

Source: "Fracked Water Explodes, Burning Family." David Lee. Courthouse News Service. 8/10/2015. Accessed 10/29/2015. http://www.courthousenews.com/2015/08/10/fracked-water-explodes-burning-family.htm

properties.Name: Ponder, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In October 2011, the Texas Commission of Environmental Quality conducted an air-quality analysis in Ponder, Texas, which showed the presence of several toxins in the air near an Atmos Energy natural gas processing plant less than a mile away. The most concerning to residents was benzene, which can cause a variety of health side effects if individuals are exposed to it long term. Individuals complained of nose bleeds and headaches caused by the pollution.

Source: “Air Quality Testing Finds Toxins in Ponder.” NBC-DFW. Oct. 27, 2011.
http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/health/Air-Quality-Testing-Finds-Toxins-in-Ponder-132746733.html

properties.Name: Rusk County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2014, a gas pipeline owned by Enbridge exploded, killing one man. The pipeline had been broken by a tractor, and the deceased man was part of a mowing team working in the area.

Source: "Enbridge gas pipeline explosion kills man in Rusk County, Texas". Reuters. Huffington Post. August 12, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/13/enbridge-gas-pipeline-explosion-texas_n_5673666.html

properties.Name: Reno, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
Barbara Brown, a woman in her 40's, has experienced problems ever since Devon Energy drilled a gas well across the street, a few hundred feet from her house. She has sinkholes in her yard that are wide enough to step in and several feet deep that she blames on injection wells. When her dogs came in contact with black soot from drilling, they contracted neurological disease and kidney failure and died within six months. Brown suffered migraines and loss of sensation in her limbs, and has been diagnosed with demyelinating disease, a category of neurological ailment that can be caused by exposure to chemicals.

Source: "Texas: When fracking comes to town". Alex Halperin. Aljazeera America. April 27, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://america.aljazeera.com/features/2014/4/texas-when-frackingcomestotown.html

Steve Brown and family, along with other Reno residents, have noticed a correlation between the arrival of injection wells and earthquakes in the area. The Browns have sinkholes in their yard and cracks throughout their home. At one point, 32 tremors occurred within the span of a few months.

Source: "Reno, Azle earthquakes leave trail of damages". ABC WFAA. January 17, 2014. Web. Accessed July 15, 2015.
http://www.wfaa.com/story/local/2015/07/15/14153824/

properties.Name: San Antonio, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2014, a man in his early 60s died after a 3,500-pound bag of fracking sand fell on him at a far North Side warehouse. The man was walking on the floor, spotting for a forklift driver, when the bag fell from a stack of three or four bags. He worked for Chalk Mountain Services, an oilfield transportation company leasing space in the building.

Source: "Bag of sand kills man at San Antonio warehouse". Alia Malik. San Antonio Express News. August 18, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Bag-of-sand-kills-man-at-San-Antonio-warehouse-5695744.php

properties.Name: Weatherford, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2011, Arron Gomas, 32, sustained brain damage when he broadsided a tractor-trailer as the truck's driver attempted to make an illegal U-turn. The truck was hauling water to a hydraulic fracturing site.

Source: "Parker County truck wreck lawsuit one of two settled for combined $11.7 million". Weatherford Democrat. June 28, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.weatherforddemocrat.com/news/local_news/parker-county-truck-wreck-lawsuit-one-of-two-settled-for/article_c48e4897-fd53-57a5-ad47-25145d209569.html

In January 2013, following the construction of a Range Resources drilling site a mile north of his property, Weatherford resident Steve Lipsky noticed that his water had started to “bubble like champagne”. Today his water supply has enough methane to ignite. Though the Environmental Protection Agency initially issued an emergency order for the contamination, they rescinded it a year later. According to documents obtained by the Associated Press, Range Resources threatened to withhold its cooperation from a national study on hydraulic fracturing, and the EPA set aside a report linking Mr. Lipsky’s contaminated water to the well just off his property. Mr. Lipsky, who is still tied up in a lawsuit with Range Resources, has said the experience has “been taking a huge toll on my family and on our life”.

Source: “EPA changed course after company protested”. Ramit Pluschnik Masti, The Associated Press. January 16, 2013.
http://news.yahoo.com/epa-changed-course-oil-company-protested-082012084.html;_ylt=AmveX8E14CsKyLcN.JfNSLQS.MwF;_ylu=X3oDMTQ2bTdpNTV2BG1pdANUb3BTdG9yeSBTY2llbmNlU0YgRW5lcmd5U1NGBHBrZwM2Yjg2NzM2OC00NWE2LTM1OWMtOTI5MC0wZTE4ZGU2YWVkYWUEcG9zAzEEc2VjA3RvcF9zdG9yeQR2ZXIDNWY2NjY5OTAtNWZiNi0xMWUyLWJlZmUtMzE1ZDMwNTQ3ZGFk;_ylg=X3oDMTFzMnBqYnA4BGludGwDdXMEbGFuZwNlbi11cwRwc3RhaWQDBHBzdGNhdANzY2llbmNlfGVuZXJneQRwdANzZWN0aW9ucw--;_ylv=3

properties.Name: Wilson County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2013, internal pressure of a Hunt Oil Co. gas well reached critical levels, forcing the evacuation of residents in a 2-miles radius of the well.

Source: "Gas well issues prompt evacuation near Kosciusko". Johnny De La Zerda Jr. Wilson County News. May 8, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.wilsoncountynews.com/article.php?id=50983&n=breaking-news-gas-well-issues-prompt-evacuation-near-kosciusko

properties.Name: Wharton County, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2014, a natural gas line owned by Enterprise Products ruptured, injuring one person and damaging a power plant. The explosion sent a fireball into the sky, and an individual driving near the line when it ruptured suffered non-life-threatening injuries. The rupture occurred on a "gathering line" -- a smaller pipeline that moves the natural gas from the wells to the processing facilities. There was some damage to the roadway and a nearby home.

Source: "Gas line ruptures in Wharton County, injuring one". Craig Hlavaty and Mike Glenn. Chron. June 27, 2014. Web. Accessed July 13, 2015.
http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/bayarea/article/Gas-line-ruptures-in-Wharton-County-injuring-one-5582181.php

properties.Name: Price, UT
properties.PopupInfo:
In November 2012, two workers were critically injured in an explosion and fire at a natural gas compressor station operated by Bill Barrett Corporation in Price, Utah. The explosion occurred when a gas line ruptured at the Dry Canyon compressor station.

Source: “2 Injured in fire at Bill Barrett Gas.” Mark Harden. Denver Business Journal. Nov. 21, 2012.
http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/news/2012/11/21/2-injured-in-fire-at-bill-barrett-gas.html

properties.Name: Plymouth, WA
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2014, a large explosion and fire at a natural gas processing plant injured four workers and led to the evacuation of about 200 people from nearby homes. Onlookers reported flames and a mushroom-shaped cloud of black smoke.

Source: "4 injured, 200 evacuated after Washington natural gas plant explosion". The Associated Press. The Oregonian. March 31, 2014.
http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2014/03/4_injured_200_evacuated_after.html

properties.Name: Brooke County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In January 2015, a 20-inch ATEX Express pipeline exploded, causing nearly 24,000 barrels of Marcellus and Utica shale ethane to burn five acres of Brooke County woodland. The accident also damaged the siding of a home roughly 2,000 feet from the blast.

Source: "24,000 Ethane Barrels Burned". Casey Junkins. The Intelligencer. January 30, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/623827.html

properties.Name: Clarksburg, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
Two Adamston Elementary school students were killed when a Mineral Wells brine tanker truck crashed in March 2013. A 43-year-old man was driving the truck, and he told the police that his breaks failed.

Source: Counselors to be at Adamston Elementary as school copes with deaths of two students. Darlene Taylor-Morgan. The Exponent Telegram. March 10, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.theet.com/article_dc588b8c-89d6-11e2-b755-001a4bcf887a.html

properties.Name: Doddridge County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In July 2013, an explosion at an Antero Resources gas well drilling site injured several workers, sending five individuals to West Penn Burn Center. Residents living nearby expressed concern for their safety and the safety of workers.

Source: "Doddridge County Residents Want Answers After Gas Well Explosion". Lauren Talotta. WBOY. July 7, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.wboy.com/story/22778144/doddridge-county-residents-want-answers-after-gas-well-explosion

In October 2013, a flash fire at an Antero Resources gas drilling site injured two workers. The accident occurred from a condensate leak as the workers were installing a new separator. Vapors ignited and caused the fire, and both workers suffered burns.

Source: "State DEP investigates well site fire, 2 injured". The Associated Press. West Virginia Gazette. October 29, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://www.wvgazette.com/News/201310290007

In October 2014, while drilling for shale gas, Antero Resources accidentally drilled into one of their own wells that was engaged in production. The accident resulted in at least 12 homes with contaminated drinking water. The incident occurred at Antero's five-well Primm Pad near West Union, and the rupture happened at a drilling depth of 641 feet. Several water wells, an existing gas well, and an abandoned well in the area were affected.

Source: "Well water contamination possible after drilling mishap". Glynis Board. WV Public Broadcasting. October 1, 2014. Web. Accessed July 9, 2015.
http://wvpublic.org/post/well-water-contamination-possible-after-drilling-mishap

properties.Name: Fayette County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2015, a CSX train carrying Bakken crude derailed, resulting in an explosion and fire. Nearly 1,000 residents were forced to leave their homes, 2,000 were without water, one home was destroyed, and power lines were damaged.

Source: "CSX says fires near rail cars will be allowed to burn out; oil will then be transferred to other tanks". Jeff Morris, Bob Aaron, Kaylin E. Searles. WCHS ABC 8. February 17, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://www.wchstv.com/news/features/eyewitness-news/stories/Fire-Still-Burns-Following-Fayette-County-Train-Derailment-82510.shtml#.VOQQsy40vzAhttp://www.wsaz.com/home/headlines/Train-Derailment-Causes-Fire-near-Montgomery-Evacuation-Underway-292096241.html

properties.Name: Glen Dale, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2015, a 4-inch pipeline rupture spilled 100 barrels of Marcellus shale condensate into Little Grave Creek, and a 12-inch gas pipeline rupture that occurred after the first caused five families to evacuate for a period of time.

Source: "'Heavy Rains' Cited in Marshall Pipeline Failure". Casey Junkins. The Intelligencer. April 11, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2016.
http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/630275/-Heavy-Rains--Cited-In-Marshall----.html

properties.Name: Jackson County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
Dusty and Tamera Hagy have sued four separate natural gas drilling companies for illegally drilling for oil on their 81-acre property. In 2008, it was confirmed that this unwarranted drilling caused harm to the family’s drinking water as each member began experiencing headaches, vomiting, and rashes. In January, 2009 the Hagy’s were forced to evacuate their home due to the damage fracking had caused, and have not yet been able to return as their lawsuit is pending.

Source: “The Hagy Story: Loopholes Shield Fracking Industry While Families Pay the Price.” Laurel Peltier. EcoWatch. Feb. 27, 2013.
http://ecowatch.com/2013/loopholes-shield-fracking-industry/

properties.Name: Kanawha County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
As of February 2015, Sharon M. Perry is suing Antero Resources Corporation, claiming that its drilling and exploration have caused her damages. Her property is in close proximity to the company's drilling, exploration, extraction, compression, pipeline, transportation and related activities. According to Perry, this activity has produced spills, emissions and discharges of hazardous gases and materials, chemicals and other industrial/hazardous wastes. Perry has been forced to breathe these emissions on a frequent basis.

Source: "Woman sues Antero for drilling, exploration". Kyla Asbury. West Virginia Record. February 11, 2015. Web. Accessed July 6, 2015.
http://wvrecord.com/stories/510588429-woman-sues-antero-for-drilling-exploration

properties.Name: Ohio County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
Becky Wieczorkowski was at home when 7,000 gallons of drilling mud from a nearby pipeline project burst free and rushed into her basement in October 2013. Everything in the basement was under mud, and she and her husband were forced to move out of their home and into a motel.

Source: "Ohio County homeowner thought she was living through an earthquake". Chris Lawrence. MetroNews. October 25, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://wvmetronews.com/2013/10/25/wetzel-county-homeowner-thought-she-was-living-through-an-earthquake/

properties.Name: Cameron, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2014, a semi truck carrying fracking sand crashed through a guard rail and went over a hill, hitting a residential building. The truck was on its way to a drilling site on U.S. 250. After crashing through the guard rail, the truck began to spill its cargo of fracking sand and its diesel fuel, causing EMS response crews to bring chemical cleanup kits. The driver jumped from the cab of the truck before it crashed through the guard rail, suffering slight injuries.

Source: "Sand truck jumps curb, hits building". Alan Olson. The Intelligencer. December 4, 2014. Web. Accessed July 8, 2015.
http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/618856.html

properties.Name: Marshall County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2010, an A B Resources gas well explosion resulted in the injury of several workers. The accident occurred when a crew drilling a natural gas well hit a pocket of methane gas that ignited, burning seven workers. The blast created a column of flame that was at least 70 feet high.

Source: "Natural gas well explosion burns 7 workers in West Virginia". Associated Press. PennLive. June 7, 2010. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2010/06/natural_gas_well_explosion_bur.html

In April 2014, a 12-inch natural gas line running near the Williams Energy Oak Grove plant construction site exploded. The line is owned by a subsidary of Williams, LP and carries unprocessed natural gas from production wells. Emergency officials believe the rupture may have been caused by a mudslide, and residents along Middle Grave Creek and Waymans Ridge were asked to evacuate their homes.

Source: "Resident describes natural gas line explosion in Marshall County". Jeff Jenkins. MetroNews. April 5, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://wvmetronews.com/2014/04/05/natural-gas-line-explosion-in-marshall-county/

In September 2013, an under-construction natural gas plant owned by Dominion caught fire. Residents living nearby expressed concerns about their safety.

Source: "Marshall County Community Wonders about Safety After Plant Fire". Jake Kauffman. WTFR 7 News. September 21, 2013. Web. Accessed July 21, 2015.
http://www.wtrf.com/story/23494046/marshall-county-community-wonders-about-safety-after-well-fire

properties.Name: Monongalia County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
Richard F. Detamore was working for Nabors Well Services as a pipeliner when he died in a traffic accident in July 2012. His widow sued Nabors Industries, claiming that her husband was forced to work for 38 hours in the 40 hours prior to the accident, thus creating unsafe working conditions.

Source: "Widow blames Nabors Industries for husband's death". Kyla Asbury. WV Record. December 14, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://wvrecord.com/stories/510604083-widow-blames-nabors-industries-for-husband-s-death

properties.Name: Moundsville, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2010, a crew drilling a new natural gas well struck a methane pocket in an abandoned mine, causing a massive explosion. The blast created a column of flames as high as 70 feet and burned for hours. Seven workers were burned in the accident, and had to be treated at the West Penn Burn Center.

Source: “Methane gas blast in West Virginia burns 7”. By the Associated Press, The Washington Post. June 8, 2010.
http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/06/07/AR2010060704791.html

properties.Name: Ritchie County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In June 2013, a water truck owned by JB Oil and Gas ran through a stop sign, hitting and killing Cheryl Horner, who was driving a truck, and her 14-year-old daughter.

Source: "UPDATE: Names Released in Fatal Crash". WTAP. June 24, 2013. Web. Accessed July 22, 2015.
http://www.thenewscenter.tv/home/headlines/Possible-Fatal-Crash-On-US-50-212602851.html

properties.Name: Sissonville, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2012, four homes went up in flames and collapsed in charred heaps after a natural gas line owned by NiSource Inc., parent of Columbia Gas, exploded in a fire that lasted for at least an hour. Five other homes suffered extensive external damage and several people were treated for smoke inhalation. Guardrails also melted, utility poles burned, an ordinarily reflective green interstate sign was burned down to white metal and the blast blew a huge hole in the road, throwing dirt, rocks and debris across the interstate.

Source: “Explosion From Gas Line Burns Interstate 77 and Homes.” John Raby and Vicki Smith . Huffington Post. Dec. 11, 2012. “I’ll be burned alive.” Rusty Marks. West Virginia Gazette. Dec. 12, 2012.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/11/sissonville-west-virginia-explosion_n_2279577.html, http://www.wvgazette.com/News/201212120060

properties.Name: Taylor County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2013, a worker was killed in an explosion at an EQT natural gas well pad near Flemington. He was attempting to transfer briny wastewater from a tank into a truck.

Source: "West Virginia EQT Explosion Kills Worker at Taylor County Natural Gas Well Pad". Vicki Smith. Huffington Post. February 15, 2013. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/15/west-virginia-eqt-explosion-natural-gas-taylor_n_2695700.html

properties.Name: Wetzel County, WV
properties.PopupInfo:
In August 2013, a landslide damaged a MarkWest Energy pipeline, causing it to rupture and spill an unidentified but potentially hazardous and explosive liquid into the nearby environment.

Source: "Landslide damages gas pipeline". Jennifer Compston-Strough. The Intelligencer. August 17, 2013. Web. Accessed July 20, 2015.
http://theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/588533/Landslide-Damages-Gas-Pipeline.html?nav=515

In April 2011, Chesapeak Energy was sued for burying drilling waste in pits. According to a lawsuit filed by Larry and Jana Rine, the company created a large lined waste pond, then dug an adjacent pond and deliberately breached it to allow the liquids to drain into the unlined impoundment.

Source: "Chesapeake Sued for Burying Drilling Waste Pits". Dee Fulton. FrackCheck WV. April 14, 2011. Web. Accessed July 26, 2015.
http://www.frackcheckwv.net/2011/04/14/chesapeake-sued-for-burying-drilling-waste-pits/

properties.Name: Oakdale, WI
properties.PopupInfo:
Judy Carey lives across the street from a frac-sand washing plant operated by Proppant Specialists, an affiliate of FracTech Services. According to Carey, "Your clothes are full of it, you can't roll your car windows down . . . You can feel it in your throat, feel it in your nose". The frac powder contains crystalline silica, which is a potentially hazardous substance when inhaled.

Source: "Sand mining surges in Wisconsin". Jason Smathers. Wisconsin Watch. July 31, 2011. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://wisconsinwatch.org/2011/07/sand-mining-surges-in-wisconsin/

properties.Name: Cooks Valley, WI
properties.PopupInfo:
Victoria Trinko owns a farm near a Badger Mining corporation sand mine that produces frac sand for use in hydraulic fracturing. She has experienced athsma, chest tightness, sneezing and coughing. She says she can feel the dust on her face and even chew on it when she goes outside.

Source: "Does Frac Sand Mining Rush in Wisconsin Threaten Public Health?" Lynne Peeples. Huffington Post. December 7, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/07/frac-sand-mining-wisconsin-health_n_2256753.html

properties.Name: Casper, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2013, a semitrailer hauling fracking fluid overturned, spilling 160 gallons of fluid. The semitrailer was carrying nearly 4,000 gallons of a fluid known as CL-23 Crosslinker, a clear, colorless liquid produced by oilfield services company Halliburton and used in hydraulic fracturing to ease the flow of fracturing fluid underground. Two of the trailer's 12 tanks were punctured and one tank's lid busted off during the semitrailer's fall.

Source: "Overturned semitrailer, fracking fluid spill shut down busy Casper intersection". Leah Todd. Star Tribune. May 30, 2013.
http://trib.com/news/local/casper/overturned-semitrailer-fracking-fluid-spill-shut-down-busy-casper-intersection/article_002d4785-ace1-5741-8726-5eadf0b729bc.html

properties.Name: Converse County, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
Kristi Mogen and her family live near a Chesapeake gas well that blew out in April 2012. Afterwards, her youngest daughter had bloody noses for 29 days, and the whole family was sick after the incident. Janice Switzer, who lives down the street from the Mogens, said her garden died shortly after the blowout because of the increased flaring of natural gas.

Source: "Drilling near homes raises residents' ire". Michelle Brownstone. Douglas Budget. October 31, 2012. Web. Accessed July 23, 2015.
http://www.douglas-budget.com/news/article_89549128-237f-11e2-9439-001a4bcf887a.html

properties.Name: Douglas, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In May 2012, a mechanical failure and worker error caused a natural gas well blowout at the Chesapeake Energy corp. site near Douglas, Wyoming. Workers at the rig didn’t properly engage wellhead lockdown pins and didn’t see and respond to an increase of drilling mud coming back out of the well. This resulted in the well venting up to two million cubic feet of gas and 31,500 gallons of oil-based drilling “mud” over nearly three days.

Source: “Mechanical failure, worker error caused Chesapeake gas well blowout in Wyoming.” Jeremy Fugleberg. Wyoming Star-Tribune. May 10, 2012.
http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/report-mechanical-failure-worker-error-caused-chesapeake-gas-well-blowout/article_6c1ed0be-9ab8-11e1-a91b-0019bb2963f4.html

properties.Name: Fremont County, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In December 2013, David Crichton, 36, suffered severe burns to his face and hands during a flash fire explosion at the Legacy Resources compressor station.

Source: "Flash fire at compressor injures man on Christmas". Katie Roenigk. The Ranger. December 26, 2013. Web. Accessed July 16, 2015.
http://dailyranger.com/story.php?story_id=10585

properties.Name: Lincoln County, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In September 2014, a storage tank fire occurred at an EOG Resources Inc. natural gas production facility, killing one worker and injuring three others. The deceased and injured were cleaning the tank when the fire ignited. A company spokesman described the incident as a "flash fire."

Source: "One dead after fire at EOG Resources' Wyoming natgas tank". Reuters. September 24, 2014. Web. Accessed July 10, 2015.
http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/24/us-usa-fire-wyoming-idUSKCN0HJ0AV20140924

properties.Name: Opal, WY
properties.PopupInfo:
In April 2014, an explosion occurred at one of the five natural gas processing units at a Williams Cos. plant near Opal, Wyoming. A fire followed the explosion, causing the entire 88-acre town of Opal to be evacuated.

Source: "Fire rages at Wyoming natural gas plant; town's evacuation lifted". Paresh Dave. Los Angeles Times. April 24, 2014. Web. Accessed July 14, 2015.
http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-natural-gas-fire-wyoming-plant-20140424-story.html#axzz2zs5uK1q2

properties.Name: Hagerman National Wildlife Refuge, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In February 2012, 3,000 gallons of drilling wastewater spilled in the Hagerman National Wildlife Refuge north of Dallas. The spill killed 84 mature oaks, cottonwoods and hackberry trees, some of which had been standing for more than 150 years on the banks of Lake Texoma.

Source: "Wastewater spills untracked in Texas, masking pollution." Mike Soraghan. E&E Reporter. November 18, 2015. Accessed: December 1, 2015. http://www.eenews.net/stories/1060028166

properties.Name: Leetsdale, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
A five-alarm fire at the Leetsdale Industrial Park broke out on November 17, 2015 when employees of the Lubrizol Corporation were mixing fracking chemicals in a production tank. People living in 72 nearby homes were evacuated. Five Lubrizol employees and three firefighters were treated at nearby hospitals or at the scene due to the incident.

Source: "Massive Fire Tears Through Leetsdale Industrial Park, Prompts Evacuations." Ralph Iannotti. CBS Pittsburgh. November 17, 2015. Accessed: December 1, 2015. http://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2015/11/17/firefighters-battling-3-alarm-leetsdale-industrial-fire/

properties.Name: Salem Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
On April 29, 2016 a natural gas pipeline, Spectra Energy’s Texas Eastern Transmission line, exploded in Salem Township. The accident scorched 40 acres of farmland around the blast site, and one man is in the hospital with third degree burns over 75 percent of his body. The cause of the blast is still being investigated. Initial analysis shows evidence of corrosion on the pipeline, which “indicates a possible flaw in the coating material” used in weld joints at the time of construction in 1981.

Source: "PA Pipeline explosion: Evidence of corrosion found." Susan Phillips. State Impact by NPR. May 4, 2016. Accessed May 12, 2016. https://stateimpact.npr.org/pennsylvania/2016/05/04/pa-pipeline-explosion-evidence-of-corrosion-found/

properties.Name: Sabine River, TX
properties.PopupInfo:
In March 2016, the Sabine River flooded its banks on the Texas-Louisiana border, inundating oil wells and fracking sites and flushing crude oil and toxic fracking chemicals into the water. Emergency management officials photographed oil sheens and plumes spreading from tipped tanks and flooded production sites. This is not the first incidence of oil contamination in Texas during floods, and in the past cattle have died within an hour of drinking water contaminated with fracking fluid. 

Source: "Texas floods washing fracking chemicals, crude oil into rivers." Chris Siron. The Dallas Morning News. May 1, 2016. Accessed May 12, 2016. http://thescoopblog.dallasnews.com/2016/05/texas-floods-washing-fracking-chemicals-crude-oil-into-rivers.html/

properties.Name: Santa Clara Waste Water Co
properties.PopupInfo: On November 18, 2014, an explosion, fire and mile-high plume of toxic gas severely injured three firefighters and 12 employees at the Santa Clara Waste Water site. Over 50 people were sent to the hospital for treatment after inhaling toxic black clouds that included chlorine dioxide, a poisonous gas. According to company officials, 80 percent of the waste water processed at the site comes from oil-field production.                                                                                                                                             Source:  "The hazardous truth". VC Reporter. 19 Nov 2015. Web. Accessed September 14, 2016.  https://www.vcreporter.com/2015/11/19/the-hazardous-truth/

properties.Name: Porter Ranch, CA
properties.PopupInfo: In October 2015, there was a massive natural gas leak at the Aliso Canyon storage facility. Officials relocated several thousand residents who said the fumes made them sick. Investigators are still looking into whether or not this leak was the result of fracking.                                                                                                                                                                 Source: "Regulators Probing Whether Fracking was Connected to Aliso Canyon Gas Well leak". Gregory J. Wilcox, Los Angeles Daily News. Jan 13, 2016. Web. Accessed Oct 3, 2016. http://www.dailynews.com/environment-and-nature/20160113/regulators-probing-whether-fracking-was-connected-to-aliso-canyon-gas-well-leak

properties.Name: Nageezi, NM
properties.PopupInfo:
In July of 2016, 36 oil storage tanks erupted in flames near Nageezi, a Navajo Nation town. The fire occurred on a WPX Energy fracking site and caused the evacuation of 55 residents, burning for several days. WPX specializes in producing oil and gas from fracking.

“Fire From New Mexico Fracking Site Explosion Keeps Burning Three Days Later.” Alejandro Davila Fragoso. Think Progress. July 14th, 2016. Accessed December 20, 2016
https://thinkprogress.org/fire-from-new-mexico-fracking-site-explosion-keeps-burning-three-days-later-984d644f5f5#.tyywow66d

properties.Name: Grady County, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
A fire at a fracking well caused $20 million of damage in January of 2016. The fire required more than 6 fire departments to extinguish in Grady County, Oklahoma. The well belonged to Continental Resources and damaged 22 oil tankers and other equipment near the well.

Source: “Firefighters Extinguish Damaging Grady Co. Fracking Fire.” K. Querry and Lorne Fultonberg. News Channel 4. January 13, 2016. Accessed december 20, 2016
http://kfor.com/2016/01/13/all-lanes-of-traffic-shut-down-due-to-large-oil-rig-fire/

properties.Name: Pawnee, OK
properties.PopupInfo:
On September 3, 2016, Oklahoma experienced its largest Earthquake on record. The earthquake struck Pawnee, OK with a magnitude of 5.8, causing the Oklahoma Geological Survey to send out the first earthquake warning in a state east of the Rocky Mountains. A growing consensus among scientists suggests that the injection of fracking wastewater underground has contributed to increases in Earthquakes in states that previously had few quakes.


Source: “Oklahoma Just Experienced It's Largest Earthquake on Record.” Jeanna Bryner. Live Science. September 8, 2016, Accessed January 3, 2017 http://www.livescience.com/56019-oklahoma-largest-earthquake-on-record.html

properties.Name: Somerset Township, PA
properties.PopupInfo:
On January 1, 2017, a large fire erupted in Bentleyville, PA. The fire engulfed four pumper trucks at a Marcellus Shale fracking site, while 16 fire departments responded to the fire. Several nearby residents fled their homes at the sight of the large flame. 

Source: “Fire Erupts at Marcellus Shale Pad in Somerset Township” Scott Beveridge. Observer-Reporter. January 1, 2017. Accessed January 3, 2017. http://www.observer-reporter.com/20170101/fire_erupts_at_marcellus_shale_pad_in_somerset_township
